{{about|the ex-wife of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte|the British knitter|Elizabeth Zimmermann}} {{Philippine name|Abellana|Zimmerman}} {{Infobox person | name = Elizabeth Zimmerman | image = CyWV bnVQAEei9m (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Zimmerman in November 2016 | birth_name = Elizabeth Abellana Zimmerman{{cite news|title=Lawyer on Duterte: 'It ain't over until it's over'|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/nation/10/13/15/lawyer-duterte-it-aint-over-until-its-over|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=14 October 2015}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|04|14}} | birth_place = [[Davao (province)|Davao]], [[Philippines]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | education = [[Ateneo de Davao University]] | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Rodrigo Duterte]]|1973|2000|end={{abbr|civ. ann.|civilly annulled}}}} | children = [[Paolo Duterte]]
[[Sara Duterte]]
Sebastian Duterte }} '''Elizabeth Abellana Zimmerman'''{{cite news|last1=Calleja|first1=Niña|title=Campaign road trip reunites Duterte, ex-wife|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/779845/campaign-road-trip-reunites-duterte-ex-wife|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=17 April 2016}} (born April 14, 1948) is a Filipina [[flight attendant]], and the former wife of Philippine President [[Rodrigo Duterte]]. ==Early life== Zimmerman was born on {{birth date|1948|04|14}},{{cite news|last1=Gitgano|first1=Flornisa|title=Duterte drops by Cebu to see ex-wife on her 68th birthday|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2016/04/15/duterte-drops-cebu-see-ex-wife-her-68th-birthday-468059|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=Sun Star Cebu|date=15 April 2016}} in [[Davao (province)|Davao province]]. Her grandfather is from Germany who migrated to the [[United States]]. She attended [[Ateneo de Davao]] and worked as a flight stewardess for [[Philippine Airlines]].{{cite news|title=‘Philandering’ Rodrigo Duterte cause of marriage annulment|url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/inside-track/100729-philandering-rodrigo-duterte-marriage-annulment|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=28 July 2015}} Zimmerman is ethnically [[Jews|Jewish]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/148217-philippines-president-rodrigo-duterte-apology-jewish-community |title=Jewish community applauds Duterte after apology |author=Ranada, Pia |work=[[Rappler]] |date=4 October 2016 |accessdate=7 October 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/05/1630535/duterte-no-offense-meant-my-ex-wife-jew |title=Duterte: No offense meant, my ex-wife is a Jew |author=Mendez, Christina |website=Philstar.com |date=5 October 2016 |accessdate=7 October 2016}} ==Politics== Zimmerman ran a bid to be elected as a city councilor of Davao City in 2001 but was unsuccessful. She joined the Byaheng Du30 bus caravan which went around Visayas and Mindanao in support of her [[Rodrigo Duterte presidential campaign, 2016|former husband's presidential bid]] at the [[Philippine presidential election, 2016|2016 Philippine presidential election]].{{cite news|last1=Alconaba|first1=Nico|title=Duterte’s ex-wife joins ‘Biyaheng DU30’ campaign in VisMin|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/777775/dutertes-ex-wife-joins-biyaheng-du30-campaign-in-vismin|accessdate=31 May 2016|work=Inquirer Mindanao|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=5 April 2016}} ==Personal life== Zimmerman was married to [[Davao City mayor]] [[Rodrigo Duterte]] (who later became [[President of the Philippines]]) for over 25 years with whom she has three children including [[Paolo Duterte|Paolo]] and [[Sara Duterte]]. She filed for a civil annulment in 1998. For a few months at the time the annulment was filed, Zimmerman had been living with her brother in Manila but occasionally visited Davao City since her children with Duterte were still studying there. Duterte has admitted that his ex-wife left him after she caught him cheating. The civil annulment was granted in 2000. After the annulment, Zimmerman remained friends with her former husband. She chose to continue using "Duterte" as part of her surname despite the annulment, saying that her marriage with Duterte has never been [[declaration of nullity|declared null]] by the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. In August 2015, Zimmerman was diagnosed with Stage 3 [[breast cancer]].{{cite news|last1=Caduaya|first1=Editha|title=Duterte and ex-wife: The ties that bind|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/114348-mayor-duterte-elizabeth-zimmerman-wife|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=29 November 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Rodrigo Duterte}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zimmerman, Elizabeth}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Davao City]] [[Category:Filipino people of American-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Filipino people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Duterte family|Elizabeth Zimmerman]] [[Category:Flight attendants]] [[Category:Ateneo de Davao University alumni]] [[Category:People with cancer]] [[Category:Spouses of Presidents of the Philippines]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person |name=Ernest Douwes Dekker |image=Douwes.jpg |alt= |caption= |birth_name=Ernest François Eugène Douwes Dekker |birth_date={{birth date|1879|10|8|df=yes}} |birth_place=[[Pasuruan|Pasoeroean]], [[East Java|Residency of Malang]], [[Dutch East Indies]] (now [[Indonesia]]) |death_date={{death date and age|1950|8|28|1879|10|8|df=yes}} |death_place=[[Bandung]], [[West Java]], Indonesia |occupation=Politician
Writer |spouse=Clara Charlotte Deije
Johanna Mussel
Haroemi Wanasita }} '''Ernest François Eugène Douwes Dekker''' also known as ''[[Setyabudi]]'' or ''Setiabudi'' (8 October 1879 – 28 August 1950) was an [[Indonesia]]n-[[Dutch people|Dutch]] [[Indonesian National Revolution|nationalist]] and politician of [[Indo people|Indo]] descent. He was related to the famous Dutch anti-colonialism writer [[Multatuli]], whose real name was Eduard Douwes Dekker ("Douwes Dekker" being their surname). In his youth, he fought in the [[Second Boer War]] in South Africa on the [[Boer]] side. His thoughts were highly influential in the early years of the Indonesian freedom movement. After Indonesian independence, he adopted the [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]] name '''Danoedirdja Setiaboedi'''. ==Early years== Douwes Dekker was born in Pasuruan, in the north eastern city of Java, 80 km south of [[Surabaya]]. His father was Auguste Henri Edouard Douwes Dekker, a broker and bank agent,{{cite web |url=http://www.inghist.nl/Onderzoek/Projecten/BWN/lemmata/bwn5/douwes_de |title=DOUWES DEKKER, Ernest François Eugène, 1879–1950|publisher=Instituut voor Nederlandse Geschiedenis |accessdate=8 January 2006}} of a Dutch family living in the then-[[Dutch East Indies]]. His [[Indo people|Indo (Eurasian)]] mother was Louisa Margaretha Neumann, of half-[[Germans|German]] and half-[[Javanese people|Javanese]] descent. Douwes Dekker's great-uncle was the famous writer [[Multatuli|Eduard Douwes Dekker]], author of ''[[Max Havelaar]]''.{{cite web |url = http://www2.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/20/pustaka/572972.htm |title = Danudirdja Setiabuddhi, 1879–1950 |publisher = [[Kompas]] |accessdate = 8 January 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051117053237/http://www.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/20/pustaka/572972.htm |archivedate = 17 November 2005 |df = dmy }} After studying in Lower School in Pasuruan, he moved to Surabaya, and later to [[Jakarta|Batavia]]. In 1897, he gained his diploma and worked on a coffee [[plantation]] in [[Malang]], [[East Java]]. Later he moved to a sugar [[plantation]] in Kraksaan, East Java. During his years in these plantations, he came in contact with ordinary [[Javanese people|Javanese]] and saw the realities of their hard work. ==Second Boer War== In 1900, along with his brothers Julius and Guido, he decided to [[Boer foreign volunteers|volunteer]] for service in the [[Second Boer War]]. They arrived in [[South African Republic|Transvaal]], and became citizens of that state. He based his actions on the belief that the [[Boer]]s were victims of [[British Empire|British]] expansionism, and as fellow descendant of the Dutch, he was obliged to help. In the course of the war, he was captured by the British and placed in an internment camp on [[Ceylon]]. Dekker was later released and returned to the Dutch East Indies via Paris in 1903. ==Indonesian struggle== In the Dutch East Indies, Dekker, then still in his twenties, started a career as a journalist, first in [[Semarang]] and later in [[Jakarta|Batavia]]. There he worked with [[Indo people|Indo]] activist [[Karel Zaalberg]], the chief editor of the newspaper ''[[Bataviaasch Nieuwsblad]]'', whom he befriended. On 5 May 1903 he married Clara Charlotte Deije, who would bear him three children. Unlike other people of European descent, he did not favour [[colonialism]], strongly advocating self-management, and finally the independence, of the Dutch East Indies. This was prompted partly by his experience in watching the lives of plantation workers and partly by discrimination he had suffered, through being only considered half-Dutch and a second-class citizen. During these times, he published many articles advocating independence, and "Indies nationalism".{{cite book |title=Indonesia, Early Political Movements|publisher=Library of Congress Country Studies |accessdate=8 January 2006}} In 1913, close associates of Douwes Dekker, including physicians [[Tjipto Mangunkusumo]] and [[Suwardi Surjaningrat]], established the Native Committee in [[Bandung]], which later became the [[Indische Party|Indische Partij]].{{cite web |url=http://countrystudies.us/indonesia/14.htm |title=The Growth of National Consciousness|publisher=[[Federal Research Division]] of the [[Library of Congress]] |accessdate=8 January 2006}} This was considered a breakthrough, because most organisations had never so openly advocated independence. In March 1913, the party claimed approximately 7000 members, approximately 5500 of whom were [[Indo people|Indo]]s (people of mixed Dutch-Indonesian ancestry) along with 1500 native Indonesians. The Colonial government quickly became worried and the party was forbidden. This led to the [[exile]] to the [[Netherlands]] of Douwes Dekker and his two Javanese associates. In exile, they worked with liberal Dutchmen and compatriot students. It is believed that the term ''Indonesia'' was first used in the name of an organization, the Indonesian Alliance of Students, with which they were associated during the early 1920s. After his party was forbidden it directly inspired the foundation of the [[Insulinde (political party)|Insulinde]] and an [[Indo people|Indo]]-European party named '[[Indo Europeesch Verbond]]' chaired by his friend [[Karel Zaalberg]] and also advocated independence. Many of the former 'Indische Partij' members joined the new party that grew to 10.000 members.Postma, Ulbe: ''Karel Zaalberg, journalist en strijder voor de Indo.'' (Publisher [[KITLV]], Leiden, 1997.) In 1918 he was allowed to return to the East Indies and was responsible for reforming the 'Insulinde' into the new 'National Indische Party' (NIP). Together with his new associate [[P.F. Dahler]] and old companion [[Tjipto Mangoenkoesoemo]], he became a prominent leader of the NIP. After the NIP was involved in the [[Surakarta]] farmers' strike he was imprisoned again by the colonial authorities in 1921.[http://www.inghist.nl/Onderzoek/Projecten/BWN/lemmata/bwn5/douwes_de Dutch Institute for History – ING.] After his release from prison in 1922, he taught in Bandung in a lower school. Two years later as head of the school, he renamed it the "Ksatrian Institute". This institute was officially recognised by the government in 1926. In the same year, he married Johanna Mussel, one of its teachers, six years after divorcing his first wife. [[Sukarno]] was a teacher at one of his schools. Penders, Christiaan Lambert Maria [http://www.papuaweb.org/dlib/bk/penders1974/01.pdf ''The life and times of Sukarno''] (Publisher: [[Sidgwick & Jackson]], London, 1974) P.20 {{ISBN|0283484144}} Later, however, his activities were branded illegal, and in 1936 he was condemned to three months in prison. He was still actively advocating independence and sharing his thoughts with other intellectuals, among them [[Sukarno]], who considered Douwes Dekker as his teacher. Later, however, his influence was overshadowed by the politics of his student Sukarno's [[Indonesian National Party]] (PNI), Islamist [[Sarekat Islam]], and [[Communist Party of Indonesia]]. During [[World War II]], Dutch authorities, who considered him a dangerous activist, exiled him, along with many Indo-European of [[Germans|German]] descent, to [[Suriname]]. He would spend years in a forest prison camp called [[Jodensavanne]]. Dekker returned to Indonesia on 2 January 1947. ==Later years== After he returned to Indonesia, he was appointed a member of the provisional parliament, or ''Komite Nasional Indonesia Pusat'' (''Indonesian National Central Committee''). In February 1947, he changed his name to ''Danudirja Setiabudi'' which means 'powerful substance, faithful spirit'. In 1947 he divorced his second wife and married the [[Indo people|Indo European]] ''Nelly Alberta Kruymel'', who had changed her name to ''Haroemi Wanasita'', in an Islamic ceremony.[http://www.inghist.nl/Onderzoek/Projecten/BWN/lemmata/bwn5/douwes_de Dutch Institute for History – ING.] In December 1948 he was lifted from his sick bed and arrested by Dutch troops, but released due to his poor health. He spent his last years in Bandung, writing his autobiography, ''70 Jaar Konsekwent''. On his seventieth birthday to his delight he witnessed the formal Dutch transfer of sovereignty to Indonesia in 1949. He died eight months later in 1950. ==Legacy== [[File:Ernest Douwes Dekker 1962 Indonesia stamp.jpg|thumb|280px|1962 Indonesian stamp in the series "National Heroes" featuring Dekker]] In Dutch literature he is portrayed as a tragic and misunderstood historic figure. However, his legacy as a national hero is still appreciated in Indonesia; a district and a main street in [[Jakarta]] are named ''[[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Setiabudi]]'' in his honour. In Bandung, there is also a main street called ''Setiabudi'', and another is named ''Ksatrian'' after his school. He was recognized as National Hero by President Sukarno. His life is recorded in a biography, '''Het Leven van EFE Douwes Dekker'', by Frans Glissenaar in 1999. ==See also== {{portal|Indonesia}} * [[Boer foreign volunteers|Boer Foreign Volunteers]] * [[P.F.Dahler]], political associate. * [[Karel Zaalberg]], colleague and political associate. ===Other Indo authors=== *[[Louis Couperus]] (1863–1923) *[[Victor Ido]] (1869–1948) *[[Maria Dermoût]] (1888–1962) *[[Edgar du Perron]] (1899–1940) *[[Beb Vuyk]] (1905–1991) *[[Rob Nieuwenhuys]] (1908–1999) *[[Tjalie Robinson]] (1911–1974) *[[Ernst Jansz]] (1948– ) *[[Marion Bloem]] (1952– ) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{Commons category|Ernest Douwes Dekker}} *Veur, Paul W. van der, ''The lion and the gadfly. Dutch colonialism and the spirit of E.F.E. Douwes Dekker'', Leiden 2006, [[KITLV]] {{National Heroes of Indonesia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Douwes Dekker, Ernest}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch Muslims]] [[Category:Dutch people of Indonesian descent]] [[Category:Indo people]] [[Category:Indonesian politicians]] [[Category:Indonesian Muslims]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Javanese descent]] [[Category:Indonesian people of German descent]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:People from Pasuruan]] [[Category:People of the Second Boer War]] [[Category:Second Boer War prisoners of war held by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Dutch prisoners of war]] [[Category:Indonesian revolutionaries]] [[Category:National Heroes of Indonesia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Frances Buss | image = Frances Mary Buss.jpg | caption = Buss, {{circa|1882}} | birth_name = Frances Mary Buss | birth_date = {{Birth date|1827|8|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1894|12|24|1827|8|16|df=y}} | death_place = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | nationality = [[England|English]] | parents = {{plainlist| * [[Robert William Buss]] * Frances Fleetwood }} | occupation = [[Headmistress]], pioneer | years_active = 1848-1894 | known_for = One of the first headmistresses at [[North London Collegiate School|North London Collegiate School for Ladies]] }} '''Frances Mary Buss''' (16 August 1827 – 24 December 1894) was a British [[headmistress]] and a pioneer of [[women's education]].{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9018290/Frances-Buss|title=Britannica Online Encyclopedia|accessdate=2008-04-07}}{{cite web|title=In Memoriam: Frances Mary Buss|url=http://nlcsarchives.daisy.websds.net/PDFFiles/MemorialBooks/NLCSMBK0005.pdf|website=North London Collegiate School|accessdate=24 October 2016}} ==Life== The daughter of [[Robert William Buss]], a painter and etcher, and his wife, Frances Fleetwood, Buss was one of six of their ten children to survive into adulthood. Her grandparents, whom she was visiting in [[Aldersgate]], sent her to a private school housed in the most basic accommodation "...to get me out of the way".A. E. Ridley, Frances Mary Buss and her work for education (1895) pg 3 Next she was sent to a similar school in [[Kentish Town]] which she remembered as simply consisting of children learning [[Lindley Murray|Murray]]'s ''[[History of English grammars|Grammar]]''. Aged 10 she attended a more advanced school in [[Hampstead]]; by the age of fourteen she herself was teaching there and by sixteen she was occasionally left in charge of the school.Elizabeth Coutts, 'Buss, Frances Mary (1827–1894)', Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, Sept 2004 Her father's career as an artist being at times unsuccessful, to help the family finances her mother set up a private school in Clarence Road, Kentish Town, in 1845, at which Frances assisted,Kamm, Josephine 'How Different From Us: A Biography of Miss Buss and Miss Beale' London: The Bodley Head (1958) and which was based on the ideas of [[Johann Heinrich Pestalozzi]]. During 1848–9, she attended evening lectures at the newly opened [[Queen's College, London|Queen's College]] in [[Harley Street]], London. She was taught by [[Frederick Denison Maurice|F. D. Maurice]], [[Charles Kingsley]], and [[R. C. Trench]], and gained certificates in French, German and Geography. To [[Dorothea Beale]], a contemporary at Queen's, she described the education she had gained there as opening 'a new life to me, I mean intellectually'.Buss to Beale, 13 Jan 1889, North London Collegiate School archives ==Career== The school was renamed the [[North London Collegiate School|North London Collegiate School for Ladies]] and moved to larger premises in Camden Street on 4 April 1850. Buss was its first Headmistress and remained so for the rest of her life. Under her headship, and with the help of family members, the school became a model for [[girls' education]]. By 1865 the school had 200 day girls, with a few boarders, but was still run as a private, family concern, with her father [[Robert William Buss]] and her brother Septimus Buss teaching [[Art]] and [[Bible|Scripture]] respectively. In July 1870 Frances Mary Buss handed over the school to trustees, and in the following year she founded the [[Camden School for Girls]] with the aim of offering more affordable education for girls. She was the first person ever to use the title Headmistress.'The North London Collegiate School 1850-1950: A Hundred Years of Girls' Education' Published by Oxford University Press (1950) Buss was at the forefront of campaigns for the endowment of girls' schools, and for girls to be allowed to sit public examinations and to enter universities. She became the founding president of the [[Association of Head Mistresses]] in 1874, a position she held until 1894,Dictionary of British Educationists By Richard Aldrich and Peter Gordon Published by Routledge (1989) {{ISBN|0-7130-0177-1}} and was also involved in establishing the Teachers' Guild in 1883 and the Cambridge Training College (later [[Hughes Hall, Cambridge|Hughes Hall]]) for training teachers in 1885. In 1869 she became the first woman [[Fellow]] of the [[College of Teachers|College of Preceptors]], helping to establish the College's professorship of the science and art of education in 1872. Her election to a Fellowship of the College in 1873 was the only public recognition she ever received.College of Teachers' Archive She was also a member of the Council of the Teachers' Training and Registration Society. Buss was also a [[suffragist]], participating in the [[Kensington Society (suffragette group)|Kensington Society]], a woman's discussion society, and the London Suffrage Committee. She is buried in the churchyard of Theydon Bois in Essex. ==Legacy== Her name is associated with that of [[Dorothea Beale]] in a satirical rhyme:
Miss Buss and Miss Beale, [[Cupid]]'s darts do not feel. How different from us, Miss Beale and Miss Buss.
In the spring of each year North London Collegiate School, North London Collegiate School Jeju (in [[South Korea]]) and [[Camden School for Girls]] all hold Founder's Day to commemorate Frances Mary Buss and her legacy. Pupils, staff and guests each carry a daffodil in memory of Miss Buss's favourite flower. The educational values that Frances Mary Buss taught at the [[North London Collegiate School]] became the model for many schools throughout the UK and overseas. This included [[Pretoria High School for Girls]], founded in [[South Africa]] by Edith Aitken, a former pupil of Miss Buss.http://hamiltonschool.pta.myweb.absamail.co.za/hamiltonhistory.htm ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nlcs.org.uk School Website] *[http://www.nlcs.org.uk/896/about-us/history-of-the-school/archives NLCS Archives] *[http://www.spartacus-educational.com/Wbuss.htm Spartacus: Frances Buss] *[http://www.warwick.ac.uk/services/library/mrc/ead/188.htm Association of Head Mistresses] *[http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cgi-bin/search2?coll_id=7239&inst_id=76 AIM25: Frances Mary Buss and family] {{Authority control}} {{Wikisource1911Enc|Buss, Frances Mary}} {{commons category|Frances Mary Buss}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buss, Frances Mary}} [[Category:English schoolteachers]] [[Category:English educators]] [[Category:Feminist studies scholars]] [[Category:English suffragists]] [[Category:1827 births]] [[Category:1894 deaths]] [[Category:School principals and headteachers]] [[Category:People educated at Queen's College, London]] [[Category:Leaders of British trade unions]] [[Category:English trade unionists]]

{{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=September 2010}} {{BLP sources|date=September 2010}} }}
'''Goetz Oertel''' (born August 24, 1934) is an American [[physicist]] and science manager.<ref name="springer" />
==Youth==
===Flight from West Prussia===
Oertel was born in [[Stuhm]], [[West Prussia]], Germany (today Sztum, Poland). In January 1945, Oertel escaped from the advancing [[Red Army]] with his parents, milling director Egon Oertel and his wife Margarete (née Wittek) westwards, initially to Gransee in Brandenburg, then continuing to Triptis in Thuringia which was captured by US forces rather than the Soviets. When Thuringia fell under Soviet control in the course of the [[Potsdam Agreement]], the flight continued by horse and carriage, further westwards to Öhringen in southwestern Württemberg. Goetz's father was able to support the family through his hobby, genealogy. His hometown, lying east of the [[Oder–Neisse line]], was transferred to Poland after the war.
===Education===
After the [[Abitur]] at the Robert-Mayer-High School in Heilbronn and first work experiences in the private economy at the energy corporation AEG in Stuttgart, Oertel commenced his studies of physics at the [[Christian-Albrechts University]] in Kiel in 1953. A son of a member of the Corps (student fraternity) Masovia, he equally sought membership in the Kiel Corps Palaiomarchia-Masovia, where he sustained in four fencing duels.<ref>Kösener Corpslisten 1996, ''' 114''', 61</ref>
==Physicist in the US==
Goetz followed his supervisor of his doctoral thesis to the US in 1957 with a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright stipend]], and got a position as physics research associate at the [[University of Maryland]]. He married Brigitte Beckmann in 1960, and became neighbor as well as friends with Karl-Ludwig Stellmacher, a German – American mathematician.
After his successful PhD promotion he was hired by [[NASA]] in January 1963 at their [[Langley Research Center]] as a researcher. The agency promoted his naturalization to US citizenship and provided him with responsibility over a current research project. He had to convince the NASA and [[General Electric]] engineers that the project was unviable and had to be restructured substantially. At the same time, his experimental research results from his PhD thesis became published and resulted in the application for two patents.
===Solar physics===
In 1967, the NASA HQ offered Goetz Oertel a senior position in Washington, D.C. and thus enabled a continuation of his theoretical work. When he was finally named leader of the program of the ATM of [[Skylab]], consequentially becoming responsible for continuously increasing roles and functions, and finally was promoted Chief of Solar Physics, he had to come to an end with his experimental work, albeit successfully.
===Nuclear energy===
In 1974, the [[Nixon administration]] drafted its Federal Executive Development Program, with the goal to reduce the isolation of the Federal ministries, specifically among the higher level civil servants, the so-called super-grades. As a consequence, management skills gained a higher weight than the academic knowledge of the subject matter. Around 8.000 mid-level civil servants had to apply for 25 positions. Oertel applied successfully and was offered „free choice“ among the Federal ministries. After the introduction course in [[Charlottesville]], South Carolina{{check|date=September 2014}} he became, for six months each, scientific advisor to the President and at the [[Office of Management and Budget]] of the President's Office – Department for Space, Science and Energy. In 1975, he was appointed Head of the Astronomy Program at the [[Ministry of Science]]{{clarify|date=September 2014}}, and in 1976 Chief of Staff of the Assistant Administrator for nuclear energy. From 1977 to 1984, he served as director for nuclear energy facilities (including nuclear waste- and secondary products of the defense sector) in the newly created [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]]. New positions at the [[Savannah River Site]] in [[South Carolina]] in Albuquerque brought responsibilities for 32,000 employees and an overall budget of USD 3 billion.
===Astronomy===
Oertel returned to the Ministry of Energy in 1985 as deputy assistant. Dealing with the consequences of the [[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]] space shuttle accident and the [[Chernobyl disaster]], the appointment to President and Chief Executive of [[Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy|AURA]] came at a suitable moment. AURA operated the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], space- and solar observatories in Arizona, New Mexico and Chile, and, more recently, also the [[Gemini Observatory]]s in Hawaii and Chile. After thirteen successful years at this position, Oertel finally declined a five-year renewal of his contract.
==Honorations==
Oertel remains an active member of The National Academy of Sciences, and continues his work for various foundations and universities, as well as for ministries of science in North- and South America. The National Academies elected him as Associate for life. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers honored him with the [[Dixy Lee Ray]] Prize. Finally, the International Astronomic Union baptized an [[asteroid]] after him: [[5074 Goetzoertel]].<ref name="springer" />
==Private life==
Oertel and his wife have one daughter and one son. He is a member of the Corps Masovia and Palaiomarchia.<ref>R. Döhler: ''Verzeichnis sämtlicher Mitglieder des Corps Masovia 1823-2005''. Potsdam 2006</ref> He is an active member of the [[Cosmos Club]] in Washington D.C.
== References == {{reflist |refs=
<ref name="springer">{{cite book |title = Dictionary of Minor Planet Names – (5074) Goetzoertel, Addendum to Fifth Edition: 2003–2005 |last = Schmadel | first = Lutz D. |publisher = [[Springer Berlin Heidelberg]] |page = 25 |date = 2006 |url = https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-540-34361-5_94 |isbn = 978-3-540-34361-5 |accessdate = 23 February 2017}}</ref>
}} <!-- end of reflist -->
== External links == * [http://www.aip.org/history/ohilist/4803.html Interview] * [http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?orb=1;sstr=5074 NASA, Asteroid ''goetzoertel''] * [http://www.aura-astronomy.org/nv/nuresult.asp?nuid=26 Retirement from AURA] * [http://translate.google.de/translate?hl=de&sl=en&tl=de&u=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.de%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DpWKScu8WKlkC%26pg%3DPA206%26lpg%3DPA206%26dq%3D%26source%3Dbl%26ots%3Ddf9pi1zfs4%26sig%3DlGxJVNWH_dihk2a4Uj5GmQ6CK1c&anno=2 The war of our childhood (G. Oertel)] * [http://translate.google.de/translate?hl=de&sl=en&tl=de&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.asme.org%2FGovernance%2FHonors%2FSocietyAwards%2FDixy_Lee_Ray_Award.cfm&anno=2 Dixy Lee Ray Award] * [http://translate.google.de/translate?hl=de&sl=en&tl=de&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sciencestorm.com%2Fpi%2FGoetz-Oertel-240274.html&anno=2 Goetz Oertel Research Grants]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox writer | name = Iraj Mirza | image = Iraj Mirza.png | birth_date = October 1874 | birth_place = [[Tabriz]], [[Persia]] | death_date = 14 March 1926 (aged 51) | death_place = [[Tehran]], Persia | occupation = Writer, poet | alma_mater = Tabriz [[Dar ul-Funun (Persia)|Dar ul-Funun]] }}
Prince '''Iraj Mirza''' ({{lang-fa|ایرج میرزا}}, literally ''Prince Iraj''; October 1874 – 14 March 1926) (titled '''Jalāl-ol-Mamālek''', {{lang-fa|جلال‌الممالک}}), son of prince Gholam-Hossein Mirza, was a famous [[Iran]]ian poet. He was a modern poet and his works are associated with the criticism of traditions. He also made translation of literary works from French into Persian.
==Life== Iraj was born in October 1874 in [[Tabriz]], northwestern Iran. His [[pedigree chart]] shows that he was a great-grandson of [[Fath Ali Shah Qajar]], the second shah of [[Qajar dynasty]] (reigned 1797–1834). Iraj's father, prince Gholam-Hossein Mirza was son of prince Malek Iraj Mirza son of Fath Ali Shah Qajar.
Gholam-Hossein Mirza, Iraj's father, was a poet laureate or the official court-poet of [[Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar|Mozaffar al-Din Mirza]]. [[Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar|Mozaffar al-Din Mirza]], the son of [[Nasser-al-Din Shah]] (the fourth shah of [[Qajar dynasty]] reigned 1848–1896), was the [[Crown Prince]] of Iran at the time. (As a tradition, all Crown Princes during Qajar era used to reside in [[Tabriz]]).
Though some sources indicate that Iraj was schooled privately, there are reliable evidences that he studied at a branch of the [[Dar ul-Funun (Persia)|Dārolfonoon]] (House of Sciences and Techniques) in Tabriz. At 15, he was fluent in [[Persian language|Persian]], [[French language|French]], [[Arabic]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]. He was also familiar with the art of [[calligraphy]]. His handwriting was very artistic and he was and still is considered as one of the famous [[List of Persian calligraphers|calligraphers of Iran]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Solati|first1=Bahman|title=Persian Words of Wisdom: Sayings and Proverbs by Masters of Persian Poetry|date=5 October 2015|publisher=Universal Publishers|isbn=1627340548|page=539}}</ref>
==Marriage and offices== In 1890, at the age of 16, Iraj got married. When he was 19, both his father and wife died.
He then took the position of his late father and became the court-poet of [[Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar|Mozaffar al-Din Mirza]] . At 22, when Mozaffar al-Din Mirza acceded to the throne in 1896 and became Mozaffar al-Din Shah; Iraj was titled as the Head of Poets (in Persian: Sadr o-Shoʻarā). He was then titled as ''Jalāl ol-Mamālek''.
Few years later, however, he left the royal court and joined the [[Tabriz]] office of Ali Khan Amin al-Dowleh who was the governor of [[Iranian Azarbaijan]]. At this time, Iraj learned [[French language|French]] and became very familiar with [[Russian language|Russian]] too.
In 1905, when Amino-Dowleh was relocated and moved to [[Tehran]], Iraj also accompanied him and soon became involved in the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]]. In 1907 when [[Ahmad Ghavam]] (Qavam os-Saltaneh), a governmental authority, was assigned to go to [[Europe]], Iraj was asked to join him. Two years later, Iraj returned to [[Tehran]] where he started to work as a staff member in the ''Office of Official Compositions'' (in Persian: Dār ol-ʻenshā).
In 1915, his first son, Ja'afar Gholi Mirza, due to some psychological problems, committed suicide.
In 1917, Iraj joined the newly established Ministry of Culture, and three years later he was transferred to the Ministry of Finance and Revenue. From 1920 to 1925 he worked as a Revenue Officer in [[Mashhad]], the capital city of Khorasan Province (now [[Razavi Khorasan]]), in northeast of [[Iran]].
At 52, Iraj moved back to [[Tehran]] where he died on March 14, 1926.
He was survived by his second son, Khosrow Iraj.
==Poems== Iraj is considered as one of the famous contemporary poets of [[Iran]] and also as the first Iranian master of colloquial poetry. In his verses he uses words from everyday speech. The origin of this tendency has come to be identified with his name. Through Iraj, poetic language was enriched with many colloquial words and expressions. His simple poetic language is also famous for its witticism and [[satire]].
During Qajar era, Iraj was influenced by the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] (1906–1911) and by the changing circumstances in the country. This fact is manifested in the particular style of poetry that he created. Modern and imported concepts, combined with what were obtained from his own thoughts, form the framework of his style. He criticizes the social conditions of the country, and the striking originality in his use of metaphor when addressing diverse social problems has been admirable by his critics.
His style is rich in the art of [[simile]]. His striking sarcasm, pungent and fanged words are pointed at the dishonest clergy, businessmen, merchants and statesmen. In addition to those colloquial poems, Iraj also composed [[elegies]] to praise [[Mozzafar-al-Din Shah]], Hassan Ali Khan Garroosy (also known as [[Amir Nezam Garroosy]], the governor of [[Iranian Azarbaijan]] (now [[East Azarbaijan]] and [[West Azarbaijan]]) and [[Kermanshah]] during Qajar era), and many other Qajar personalities. His praise never shaded into flattery. Iraj also composed very nice [[Masnavi (poetic form)|massnawi]] and [[qat'aa]] on the raising and education of children, maternal affection, love and romance.
He was an enlightened and innovative poet, and tended towards European thought.
Despite his famous technical skills, he sometimes used similar cases of rhyme, which is considered by some poetry researchers as an intentional rejection of strict traditional poetical rules. Although Iraj was one of the pioneers of the innovative movement in the Persian poetry, he never thought of abandoning the rules of the classic poetry. Some scholars believe that because of the time in which he lived, his depth of literary knowledge and his familiarity with [[French language|French]] and other foreign languages, he could also have been one of the masters of free verse if he wanted to.
He is particularly famous for his [[Pederasty|pederastic]] and satirical poetry.
Among many poems that Iraj composed, his well-known poems include Satan (in Persian: Ebleess), Mother (in Persian: Maadar), A Letter to a Poet [[Aref Ghazvini]] (in Persian: Arefnameh), Woman's Picture (in Persian: Tassvir-e Zan), Story of the Veil or Hijab (in Persian: hejab) and the Story of Zohreh and Manouchehr (in Persian: Daastan-e Zohreh o Manouchehr), which is based on [[William Shakespeare]]'s [[Venus and Adonis (Shakespeare poem)|Venus and Adonis]].
In Mother, the poet describes a child's affection for his/her mother and how the mother nurtures the child from birth onwards. The words Iraj uses are so exquisitely descriptive and lovely not only in its original Persian but also in translated versions.
The Story of Zohreh and Manouchehr is one of his famous poetic works. Here Iraj tells the story based on the [[Greek mythology|Greek myth]] of Venus and Adonis. In this poem, Zohreh leaves the gods and comes to Earth, where she is overcome by the pleasing charm of Manouchehr in his armor. He rejects her advances while Zohreh attempts her first seduction. She goes to great pains to explain the beauty of lovemaking and she finally goes her own way as she returns to the gods.
(Just for the record: On December 8, 2004 the last Iranian movies launched in France was The Story of Zohreh and Manouchehr directed by [[Mitra Farahani]]. The film had already participated in [[Berlin]] film festival and several other international events and attracted many viewers).
Iraj was known to believe that the status of Iranian women at his time was devastatingly reminiscent of the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]]. Iraj could not bear to see that life was intolerable, unbearable and miserable for the courageous and valorous women of Iran. That was why he composed the very powerful and memorable pieces of Woman's daily lives in his poems.
==Tomb== [[File:Irajmirza.JPG|thumb|Iraj Mirza's tomb]] His tomb is in [[Zahir-od-dowleh cemetery]] between [[Darband, Tehran|Darband]] and [[Tajrish]] located in [[Shemiran]], north of [[Tehran]].
== Works == * Poems Divan * Masnavi of Zohre o Manuchehr (in Persian, not completed) * Masnavi of Arefnameh * Iraj Literary Works * Romeo and Juliet (Translation from French)
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [http://www.irandokht.com/editorial/print.php?area=pro&sectionID=8&editorialID=956&PHPSESSID=a7a7eabffcce4a5d07d55a34148a73cc Iraj Mirza Jalaalol-Mamalek]: A Reference Article on the First Iranian Master of Colloquial Poetry by [[Manouchehr Saadat Noury]] * A survey of biography, thoughts, and works and ancestors of Iraj Mirza, Dr. Mohammad-Ja'far Mahjub, Golshan Printing House, Tehran, 1977 * Mo'in Persian Dictionary, Amir Kabir Publishers, Vol.5, * From Saba To Nima, Vol. 1, Yahya Aryanpur, Tehran, Zavvar Publishers, Tehran
==External links== {{Commons category|Iraj Mirza}} * Photographs of the grave of Iraj Mirza, [[Zahir o-dowleh|Zahir od-Dowleh]] cemetery: [http://inlinethumb08.webshots.com/39431/2487643650061594669S600x600Q85.jpg (1)], [http://inlinethumb62.webshots.com/43261/2263348170061594669S600x600Q85.jpg (2)]. * "Aman az in Del" sung by [[Ghamar]] on Iraj Mirza's death [https://web.archive.org/web/20111109082815/http://www.setar.info/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86:tasnif-ghamar-aman-az-in-del&catid=39:audio-ressources&Itemid=66]
{{Persian literature}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Iraj Mirza}} [[Category:Iranian poets]] [[Category:Iranian satirists]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani poets]] [[Category:People of the Persian Constitutional Revolution]] [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1926 deaths]] [[Category:Qajar princes]] [[Category:19th-century Iranian people]] [[Category:20th-century Iranian people]] [[Category:Iranian male poets]] [[Category:Poets from Tabriz]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2017}} {{no footnotes|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Itsik Moshe | image = Itsik Moshe.JPG | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|12|31}} | birth_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = * Chairman of Israeli House, the organization concentrated on Israeli Hasbara, from 2013 * Chairman of Israel Georgia Chamber of Business, from 1996 | years_active = | known_for = * Head of the Jewish Agency representative in the Caucasus and Central Asia, from 1990 | notable_works = }} '''Itsik Moshe''' ({{lang-he|איציק משה}}) was born on December 31, in 1959 and is currently President of the Israel-Georgia Chamber of Business and the founder and Chair of Israeli House, the organization concentrated on Israeli Hasbara in the former USSR. Formerly he was the representative of the Jewish Agency in 5 USSR countries and today continues de facto representation of Israel, after he achieved significant successes while being de jure representative.
== Biography == He immigrated to Israel in 1971 from Georgia with his parents Anna and Ruben, a religious Zionist family. After rapid absorption, he continuous studding in religious school of Torah in Petah Tikva. He was elected as the Student Council chair. After graduating from the high school served in the air forces, as part of the reserve and was named an honorary soldier. As part of his academic studies at the University of Tel Aviv, he received two bachelor's degrees in sciences of education and technologies. In 1987, during his studies he became the Chairman of Student Unity and editor of newsletter "Meitar" at the university. Despite career advancement in the department of communication, left his job in 1988 in favor of the Zionist challenge offered to him by WUJS (World Union of Jewish students) for the purpose of introducing the organization to the Soviet Union. In 1989, during the Soviet regime established the first mission of WUJS in the capital of Georgia, Tbilisi and after that in other countries of the Soviet Union. In 1989, he was elected as the first representative of the Jewish Agency in Soviet Union and established first international official representation center in Soviet Socialist Republic of Georgia. Until 1992 Itsik Moshe served as the head of the Jewish Agency Representation Centers in South Caucasus and Central Asia. In 1995 achieved the highest professional role and became the director of the central mission of Jewish Agency located in Moscow. This office supervised all other representation centers and representatives in the CIS. Since 1996 serves as President of the Israel-Georgia Chamber of Business – the organization which has already become the main bridge between the countries in the fields of culture, business and public relations. In 2012, expressed his protest in media and criticized publicly the decision N67/19 of the United Nations General Assembly, where Georgia, along with 138 countries, voted in favor of the Palestinian side. After this decision the idea of opening of Hasbara campaign has been created. In 2013 he founded Israeli House, which represents the organization of Israeli Hasbara in the Former Soviet Union and aims to strengthen the links between the friendly states. At the same time he is the Chairman of the Association of Friends of the Museum of Prehistory located in the Upper Galilee and invited member of the Knesset Lobby for the Promotion of a Solution for the Israeli-Arab Conflict. Itsik Moshe is married to Alice Moshe and father of 2 children, Yamit Moskovich (Hi-tech specialist) and Yaniv Moshe (businessman).
== Initiatives and activities == In 1975 he arranged the march of the youth from the center of the country to the settlement of Elon Moreh. In 1988 established the first branch of WUJS in the Soviet Union. In 1989 conducted the first international conference of Jewish students in Israel as the part of WUJS activities. In the conference participated delegations from the Soviet Union for the first time. In 1989 established the first representation center of the Jewish Agency in Soviet Socialist Republic of Georgia. In 1990 arranged the first historic conference in Tbilisi, in the period of “Iron Curtain”, while this kind of activities were prohibited by the totalitarian Soviet rule. Delegations of Jewish organizations from 46 cities of the Soviet Union attended the conference. In 1990-1992 opened 5 Representation Centers of the Jewish Agency in FSU (South Caucasus and Central Asia). In 1991 supported establishing two representation centers of JOINT in the Caucasus. In 1993 he founded the group of friends of Israel and the Jewish Agency in participation of the local governments of post-soviet states. In 1996 established the first bi-national chamber of business in Georgia, the Israel-Georgia Chamber of Business (tourism, economy and representing Israeli interests). In 2013 in cooperation with the Knesset established pilot project of Israeli House (in former Soviet Union) which later in 2016 became member of [http://www.europeanallianceforisrael.org/ EAI - European Alliance for Israel]. In 2016 conducted the first international forum of Hasbara in Tbilisi and introduced the model to developing 100 Hasbara representation centers around the globe without Israeli Governmental expenditures. Furthermore, he was the organizer of 15 economic forums between Israel and Georgia in order to promote cooperation between the City Halls of Jerusalem and Tbilisi, as well as between Governmental authorities of Israel and Georgia, to deepen working links between Georgian Parliament and the Knesset. In 2017 a cooperation between Israeli House, the Ministry of Culture of Georgia and the [http://www.jewisheritage.org/web/ AEPJ - The European Association of Jewish Heritage] has been launched regarding the promoting of Jewish Heritage in Georgia.
== Typical views == The philosophy of his life is based on three main points: # Israeli and Jewish activities abroad - under the activities he consider the necessity of reforms in the Jewish world after the Great Allyiah. # Israeli Hasbara - strengthening Hasbara policy led by the slogan "Let’s do and let them hear!" deepening the links with friendly countries without mediators and parochial organizations of the same ethnic origin or nationality. # The necessity of full Israelization - Itsik Moshe considers the ethnic gap and antipathy as the greatest challenge and danger to Israel society, which still continuously develops in the newly repatriated groups in Israel and stays unsolvable. He also believes "complete disengagement from the culture and lifestyle of the past" is the only way to reach complete Israelization and Absorption. It should be noted that his opinions in these fields create an atmosphere of confrontation with Georgian Jews and other groups, as well as International Jewish Organizations (which he represented in the past) and institutions and business persons, who use the existing cultural ghettos as the means of achieving their political success.
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}

October 14, 2015. * [http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/in-tbilisi-georgia-a-celebration-of-25-years-of-aliyah/ In Tbilisi, Georgia, a Celebration of 25 Years of Aliyah]. December 24, 2014. * [http://cbw.ge/economy/georgia-israel-economic-perspectives-and-cooperation-mechanisms/ Georgia-Israel: Economic Perspectives and Cooperation Mechanisms]. {{For|other persons by the same name|Johan Botha (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} [[File:Ariadne auf Naxos at Hamburgische Staatsoper 2012 - Photo No 209 by Monika Rittershaus cropped.jpg|thumb|Botha as Tenor/Bacchus in ''[[Ariadne auf Naxos]]'' with [[Anne Schwanewilms]], [[Hamburg State Opera]], 2012]] '''Johan Botha''' (19 August 1965 – 8 September 2016) was a South African operatic [[tenor]].
==Life and career== Born in [[Rustenburg]], South Africa, Botha began his vocal training with Jarmilla Tellenger from the age of 10 through 17. He then served for two years in the South African Air Force before pursuing further studies in Pretoria with Eric Muller. His voice initially was trained as a bass-baritone and his first opera performance was portraying the title role in a student production of Verdi's ''[[Falstaff (opera)|Falstaff]]''. As his studies progressed under Muller his voice moved towards that of a tenor.<ref name="ON">{{cite news|url=http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2008/2/Features/Singing_Saved_His_Life.html|title=Singing Saved His Life|work=[[Opera News]]|date=February 2008|volume=72|number=8|author=Richard Dyer}}</ref> In 1990 he moved to Europe and became a longtime pupil of Irmgard Hartmann.<ref name="ON"/>
Botha made his professional stage debut at the municipal theatre in [[Roodepoort]] as Max in ''[[Der Freischütz]]'' in 1989. He then became a member of the opera chorus at the [[Bayreuth Festival]] in 1990. In 1991 he sang Riccardo in ''[[Un ballo in maschera]]'' at the [[Pfalztheater]] [[Kaiserslautern]]. This was followed by performances at opera houses in Dortmund, Hagen, Hildesheim and Bonn.<ref name="ON"/> His international breakthrough occurred in 1993 at the [[Opéra Bastille]] as Pinkerton in [[Puccini]]'s ''[[Madama Butterfly]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jahn|first1=George|title=South African tenor Johan Botha dies at age 51|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/south-african-star-tenor-johan-botha-dies-at-age-51/2016/09/08/0daa9cbc-75a5-11e6-9781-49e591781754_story.html|accessdate=8 September 2016|work=Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|date=8 September 2016}}</ref> Since then he performed at leading opera venues around the world such as the [[Metropolitan Opera]], [[Vienna State Opera]] which made him a [[Kammersänger]] in 2003, [[Opera Australia]], [[Royal Opera House]] (London), [[La Scala]] and the [[Salzburg Festival]].
[[File:Wiener Zentralfriedhof - Gruppe 40 - Johan Botha (1).jpg|thumb|upright|Botha's grave, [[Vienna Central Cemetery]]]] He died of cancer on 8 September 2016 at the age of 51.<ref>{{cite news|title=Johan Botha, tenor with a gloriously large voice and physique – obituary|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/obituaries/2016/09/08/johan-botha-tenor-with-a-gloriously-large-voice-and-physique--ob/|accessdate=8 September 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=8 September 2016}}</ref> At the time of his death Botha lived in Vienna, Austria, with his wife Sonja and two sons.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Woolfe|first1=Zachary|title=Johan Botha, Operatic Tenor in Difficult Roles, Dies at 51|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/09/arts/music/johan-botha-dies.html|accessdate=8 September 2016|work=New York Times|date=8 September 2016}}</ref> He was buried at the [[Vienna Central Cemetery]].
==Recordings== Johan Botha is the most recorded South African opera singer in history:
*[[Eugen d'Albert|d'Albert]]: ''[[Tiefland (opera)|Tiefland]]'' under [[Bertrand de Billy]] (2006) Oehms OC 312 *[[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]]: [[Stabat Mater (Dvořák)|Stabat Mater]] (2001) *[[Charles Koechlin]]: ''The Jungle Book'' (1994) *''The [[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]] Experience'' (1995) *[[Gustav Mahler|Mahler]] [[Symphony No. 8 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 8]] under [[Pierre Boulez|Boulez]] and [[Bertrand de Billy]] *Puccini: ''[[Turandot]]'' under [[Valery Gergiev|Gergiev]] (DVD) *[[Richard Strauss]]: ''[[Daphne (opera)|Daphne]]'' under [[Semyon Bychkov (conductor)|Bychkov]] *Richard Strauss: ''[[Elektra (opera)|Elektra]]'' under [[Daniel Barenboim|Barenboim]] *Richard Strauss: ''[[Friedenstag]]'' under [[Giuseppe Sinopoli|Sinopoli]] *Richard Strauss: ''Taillefer'' *[[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]: ''[[Aida]]'' under [[Daniele Gatti|Gatti]] (DVD) *Verdi: [[Requiem (Verdi)|Requiem]] under Sinopoli *[[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]: ''[[Lohengrin (opera)|Lohengrin]]'' under Bychkov *Wagner: ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]'' under [[Christian Thielemann|Thielemann]](DVD) *Wagner: ''[[Tristan und Isolde]]'' under Barenboim *Wagner: The Duet Scenes (''Tristan und Isolde'') under Bertrand de Billy *Wagner: ''[[Die Walküre]]'' under Thielemann (CD and DVD) *[[Ioan Holender]] Farewell Concert (Gala from the [[Vienna State Opera]]) (DVD) *Italian Arias (2001) *Wagner Tenor Arias *Vienna State Opera Gala (DVD) *Wiener Staatsoper Live: Beethoven | Wagner | Strauss (issued Feb 2017, Orfeo International CD)

{{Recentism|date=February 2010}} {{Expand German|Joerg Tauss|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Jörg Tauss |image = Joerg tauss 2005.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Jörg Tauss in 2005 |office = Member of the [[Bundestag]] |term_start = [[German federal election, 1994|1994]] |term_end = [[German federal election, 2009|2009]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|07|05|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Stuttgart]], [[Baden-Württemberg]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = {{flag|Germany}} |party = [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]] (1971–2009)
[[Pirate Party Germany]]
(2009–2010) |occupation = Insurance salesman |website = [http://www.tauss.de/ www.tauss.de] }} '''Jörg Tauss''' (born 5 July 1953) is a [[Germans|German]] politician and former member of the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]] (SPD). He was born in [[Stuttgart]]. From 2000 to 2009, Tauss was the spokesperson of the Education and Research workgroup of the SPD in the [[Bundestag]]. He also served within that time as regional party general secretary for [[Baden-Württemberg]]. On 6 March 2009, his home and offices in [[Berlin]] and [[Karlsruhe]] were raided by the [[Landeskriminalamt|LKA]]s of both Berlin and Baden-Württemberg in a search for [[child pornography]] which he had allegedly obtained on his mobile phone. Although he claimed that the raid and investigation were politically motivated, he resigned from all government posts on 7 March, and was stripped of his [[parliamentary immunity]] on the same day. Prosecutors began the investigation after they had obtained access to phone numbers and addresses found on the mobile phone of a [[Bremerhaven]] man who was suspected of participation in a child pornography ring. He stated on 11 March that he had purchased the material only for investigation purposes pertinent to his office. He reports that his research suggests that child pornography is typically distributed by [[Multimedia Messaging Service|MMS]] and traditional mail, so that [[Internet censorship|blocking websites]] is ineffective. On 20 June 2009, Tauss announced he was leaving the SPD for the [[Pirate Party Germany]] in protest against that party's support of legislation that would block child pornography websites, which he said would set up a technical infrastructure of [[Internet censorship in Germany|censorship]] without judicial review.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Jörg Tauss verlässt die SPD, um "Pirat" zu werden |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/article3961700/Joerg-Tauss-verlaesst-die-SPD-um-Pirat-zu-werden.html |work=[[Die Welt]] |publisher= |date=June 20, 2009 |accessdate= |language=German}}{{cite news|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/capress/090620/world/eu_germany_internet_curbs|title=Lawmaker quits German governing party over Internet curbs aimed at halting child porn|date=June 20, 2009|publisher=[[Yahoo]]|agency=[[The Canadian Press]] / [[Associated Press|AP]]|accessdate=2009-06-20}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Jörg Tauss zu seinem Austritt aus der SPD |url=http://www.tauss.de/index.php?nr=440&menu=1|work=Website of Jörg Tauss |publisher= |date=June 20, 2009 |accessdate= |language=German}} On 1 July, Tauss appealed against the law because of formal reasons at the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Federal Constitutional Court]] in Karlsruhe.{{cite news|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/Verfassungsbeschwerde-gegen-Netzsperren-Gesetz--/meldung/141425 |title=Verfassungsbeschwerde gegen Netzsperren-Gesetz |accessdate=2009-07-01 |date=2009-07-01 |publisher= [[Heinz Heise|Heise Verlag]] |language=German}} On 8 September 2009, he was stripped of his parliamentary immunity and the next day he was formally charged.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8247060.stm | work=BBC News | title=German MP charged over child porn | date=September 9, 2009 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}} In May 2010 he got a suspended prison sentence of 15 months. The judge concluded that he had been active in the online child pornography scene for private reasons rather than out of political motives relating to his parliamentary work. However, the judge did not think his motivation had necessarily been sexual, it could have been sheer curiosity. 'This is a judgement which I cannot live with and do not want to live with,' Tauss said after the trial. He plans to appeal the verdict.[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1559195.php/German-politician-sentenced-for-child-porn-Roundup]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jörg Tauss}} * [http://daten.tauss.de/StellungnahmeTauss110309.pdf Tauss′ own press release on accusation of child pornography] {{small|March 11, 2009}} (PDF, German) * [http://www.tauss-gezwitscher.de/ Tauss′ website] * [http://www.tauss.de/ Tauss′ old website] * {{DNB portal|114735654|TYP=}} * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/tauss Tauss′ profile] on [[Flickr]] * {{YouTube|user=JoergTauss|title=Tauss}} * [https://www.twitter.com/tauss Tauss′ profile] on [[Twitter]] * [http://www.solidaritaet-mit-joerg-tauss.de/ Solidaritaet mit Jörg Tauss] – A German website that defends Tauss {{Pirate Party}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tauss, Jorg}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Bundestag for Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:People from Stuttgart]] [[Category:Social Democratic Party of Germany politicians]] [[Category:21st-century German politicians]] [[Category:Members of Chaos Computer Club]] [[Category: German politicians convicted of crimes]]

{{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox person | name = Karen Lewis | image = File:Karen Lewis.png | image_size = 220px | caption = Lewis speaking at [[Daley Plaza]] during the protest of Chicago school closings, 2013 | birth_name =Karen Jennings[http://dartmouthalumnimagazine.com/articles/karen-jennings-lewis-%E2%80%9974 Dartmouth Alumni Magazine - Karen (Jennings) Lewis ’74] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|7|20}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | other_names = | education = B.A. Sociology and Music
M.A. Inner City Studies | alma_mater = [[Kenwood Academy]]
[[Mount Holyoke College]]
[[Dartmouth College]]
[[Northeastern Illinois University]] | occupation = [[Chicago Public Schools]] Chemistry teacher, [[labor leader]] | organization = [[Chicago Teachers Union]] | known_for = President of the Chicago Teachers Union since 2010 | spouse = {{marriage|Arnold Glenn|1973|1984}}
{{marriage|John Lewis|2001}} | yearsactive = 1987–present }} '''Karen Lewis''' (née '''Jennings''';{{Cite web|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/November-2012/Karen-Lewis-Street-Fighter/|title=Karen Lewis, Street Fighter|website=Chicago magazine|access-date=2016-04-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://betternewspapercontest.com/assets/538/attachments/197682915552ea42a44a925_0.pdf|title=Chicago Teachers Union President Karen Lewis on why she converted to Judaism 20 years ago and the role it plays in her life and work|last=|first=|date=July 5, 2013|website=Better Newspaper Contest|publisher=Chicago Jewish News|access-date=April 19, 2016}} July 20, 1953){{citation needed|date=August 2015}} is an [[Americans|American]] [[Chicago Public Schools]] teacher and [[labor leader]]. She is the current president of the [[Chicago Teachers Union]], local 1 of the [[American Federation of Teachers]]. She is a former [[King College Prep High School]] and [[Lane Technical High School]] chemistry teacher, her occupation for 22 years before becoming president of the teachers union. She is a graduate of Dartmouth College. ==Early life== Lewis is the daughter of a family of teachers. She left [[Kenwood Academy|Kenwood High School]] (now Kenwood Academy) after her junior year to attend [[Mount Holyoke College]]. She transferred to [[Dartmouth College]] in 1972 and is the only African American woman in the class of 1974, with a degree in sociology and music.Greg Hinz (August 12, 2013), [http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20130810/ISSUE01/308109979/so-you-think-you-know-karen-lewis "So you think you know Karen Lewis?"] Crain's Chicago, Business. A widow, her second husband is a former Chicago schools physical education teacher. ==Chicago Teachers Union== Lewis is the president of the Chicago Teachers Union. She has been a member of the union since 1988. In 2010, Lewis, running with the Caucus of Rank and File Educators (CORE), gained control over the CTU by winning 60% of the vote in a run-off election.{{cite news|last=Canon|first=Ramsin|title=Caucus of Rank-and-File Educators (CORE) Takes Over Chicago Teachers Union|url=http://gapersblock.com/mechanics/2010/06/12/caucus-of-rank-and-file-educators-core-takes-over-chicago-teachers-union/|newspaper=Gapers Block|date=June 12, 2010|accessdate=September 11, 2012}} CORE ran an aggressive grassroots organizing campaign, and took a strong stance against school privatization.{{cite news|last=Canon|first=Ramsin|title=The Education Revolt: The Chicago Model's Fallout|url=http://gapersblock.com/mechanics/2010/05/03/the-education-revolt-the-chicago-models-fallout/|newspaper=Gapers Block|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=September 11, 2012}} CORE accused the incumbent United Progressive Caucus (UPC) of capitulating to corporate interests, silencing dissent within the union, and collaborating with the city to prevent union outreach at schools.{{cite news|last=Abowd|first=Paul|title=Chicago's Rank and File Educators Well-Positioned Against "Play it Safe" Incumbents|url=http://labornotes.org/2010/06/chicagos-rank-and-file-educators-well-positioned-against-play-it-safe-incumbents|newspaper=Labor Notes|date=June 7, 2010|accessdate=September 11, 2012}} CORE quickly took action to distinguish itself from UPC, the previous caucus controlling the CTU, reaffirm its grassroots support, and launch a campaign to defend public education. The new leadership cut pay for union officers and used the savings to expand outreach.{{cite news|last=Sustar|first=Lee|title=Chicago Teachers Draw a Line|url=http://www.indypendent.org/2012/08/31/chicago-teachers-draw-line|newspaper=The Indypendent|date=August 31, 2012|accessdate=September 11, 2012}} CORE represented a major bloc of dissent at the 2012 AFT convention, and held signs in protest of [[Race to the Top]] during a speech from Vice President [[Joseph Biden|Joe Biden]].{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Norm|title=@AFT - Chicago Teachers Protest RTTT During/After Biden Speech|url=http://ednotesonline.blogspot.com/2012/07/aft-chicago-teachers-protest-rttt.html|newspaper=Ed Notes Online|date=July 30, 2012|accessdate=September 11, 2012}} ===2012 Strike=== In early September 2012 she led the Chicago Teachers Union on a 10-day strike. Emerging victorious, the union softened the proposed teacher evaluation system, prevented the instituting of merit pay, and ensured protections for veteran teachers in phased out schools.Hirst, Ellen Jean, and Delgado, Jennifer (September 19, 2012), [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-09-19/news/chi-todays-assignment-seal-deal-with-chicago-teachers-20120918_1_chicago-teachers-union-chicago-students-first-day "It's back to school again for Chicago students"], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. Prior to the strike she went through several months of negotiations with Chicago mayor [[Rahm Emanuel]] and Emanuel appointee [[Chicago Public Schools]] board president [[Penny Pritzker]]. Lewis claimed that during a disagreement over lengthening the school day, Emanuel said, "Fuck you, Lewis."Rossi, Rosalind (September 9, 2011), [http://www.suntimes.com/news/education/7558652-418/teachers-union-president-says-mayor-emanuel-exploded-at-her.html "Teachers union president Mayor Emanuel ‘exploded’ at her"], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. === Awards === 2002 – National Board Certified Teacher in the area of Science for adolescents and young adulthood.{{cite news|last=May|first=Audrey|title=Karen Lewis Biography |url=http://www.fairtest.org/sites/default/files/KarenLewisBio.pdf|newspaper=Chicago Teachers Union|year=2016|accessdate=February 9, 2016}} 2015 – The [[Deborah W. Meier]] Hero in Education Award, presented by [[Fairtest]]. 2015 – The Mary E. Smith Foundation named a scholarship after Lewis: "The Karen Lewis CTU-CPS Excellence in Science Award."{{cite news|last=Smith-Woodson|first=Tiffany|title=The Karen Lewis CTU-CPS Excellence in Science Award |url=https://cps.academicworks.com/opportunities/797|newspaper=Academic Works, Inc.|year=2015|accessdate=August 3, 2015}} == Potential 2015 mayoral candidacy == In July 2014, Lewis set up an exploratory committee to consider running for [[Chicago mayoral election, 2015|mayor of Chicago in 2015]].{{cite news |first=Natasha|last=Koerecki |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-politics/7/71/162584/karen-lewis-inches-closer-to-run-crafting-exploratory-committee |title=Karen Lewis inches closer to run — crafting exploratory committee |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=July 15, 2014 |accessdate=August 5, 2015}} In a poll from the same month, Lewis bested Emanuel 45-36 in a hypothetical electoral contest.{{cite news|url=http://politics.suntimes.com/article/chicago/exclusive-poll-karen-lewis-could-give-rahm-run-his-money/mon-07142014-334pm|title=Exclusive poll: Karen Lewis could give Rahm run for his money|last=Korecki|first=Natasha|date=July 14, 2014|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717041556/http://politics.suntimes.com/article/chicago/exclusive-poll-karen-lewis-could-give-rahm-run-his-money/mon-07142014-334pm|archivedate=July 17, 2014|df=}} On October 13, 2014, her exploratory committee announced that she would not run, citing health issues (see section below).{{cite news |first=Juan, Jr.|last=Perez|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-karen-lewis-not-running-for-chicago-mayor-20141013-story.html |title=Karen Lewis will not run for Chicago Mayor |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=October 13, 2014|accessdate= }} ==Personal life== She is a convert to [[Judaism]].{{Cite web|url=http://betternewspapercontest.com/assets/538/attachments/197682915552ea42a44a925_0.pdf|title=Chicago Teachers Union President Karen Lewis on why she converted to Judaism 20 years ago and the role it plays in her life and work|last=|first=|date=July 5, 2013|website=Better Newspaper Contest|publisher=Chicago Jewish News|access-date=April 19, 2016}} ===Health === On October 9, 2014, Lewis was hospitalized for a "serious illness".{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-ctu-karen-lewis-health-20141008-story.html |title=CTU may offer details today on Karen Lewis' health |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=October 9, 2014 |date=October 9, 2014}} On October 13, a source confirmed that Lewis had been diagnosed with a cancerous brain tumor.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Karen-Lewis-Has-Brain-Tumor-Source-279087441.html?_osource=SocialFlowFB_CHBrand|title=Karen Lewis Has Brain Tumor: Source|first=Mary Ann|last=Ahern|work=[[WMAQ-TV]] NBC Chicago|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lewis, Karen}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:American Federation of Teachers people]] [[Category:American labor leaders]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Chicago]] [[Category:Leaders of organizations]] [[Category:Mount Holyoke College alumni]] [[Category:Dartmouth College alumni]] [[Category:African-American Jews]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:Educators from Illinois]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{for|the ethnic group from [[Myanmar]]|Kayan people (Burma)}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = '''Kayan people''' | image = [[File:Kajandajakfrau.jpg|250px]] | caption = "The Tattooing of a Married Kayan Woman," (c. 1896-98), photograph by [[William Henry Furness III]]. Illustration from ''The Home-Life of Borneo Head-Hunters'' (1902). The Kayan is an indigenous tribe from the island of [[Borneo]]. The Kayan people are categorised as a part of the [[Dayak people]] of [[Borneo]]. | population = 30,000 | popplace = '''[[Borneo]]:''' | region1 = {{flag|Malaysia}} ([[Sarawak]]) | pop1 = 13,400 (1980) | ref1 = <ref>{{cite book|author=William W. Bevis|title=Borneo log: the struggle for Sarawak's forests|year=1995|publisher=University of Washington Press|page=152|isbn=0-2959-7416-8}}</ref> | region2 = {{flag|Indonesia}} ([[East Kalimantan]] & [[North Kalimantan]]) | pop2 = ''no census'' | ref2 = | langs = [[Kayan-Murik languages]] ([[Kayan language (Borneo)|Kayan language]]), [[Indonesian language]], [[Malaysian language]] ([[Sarawak Malay]]) | rels = [[Christianity]] (predominantly), [[Islam]], [[Kaharingan]] | related = [[Bahau people]], [[Kenyah people]] }}
Being an indigenous tribe in [[Borneo]], the '''Kayan people''' are similar to their neighbours, the [[Kenyah people|Kenyah]] tribe, with which they are grouped together with the [[Bahau people]] under the [[Apo Kayan people]] group.
The population of the Kayan ethnic group may be around 27,000.<ref>[http://cache.britannica.com/eb/article-9044919 ''Kayan'' in the Encyclopædia Britannica] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614150107/http://cache.britannica.com/eb/article-9044919 |date=14 June 2006 }}, retrieved on 12 August 2006, from Encyclopædia Britannica Premium Service.</ref> They are part of a larger grouping of people referred collectively as the [[Orang Ulu]], or upriver people. Like some other [[Dayak people]], they are known for being fierce warriors, former [[headhunting|headhunters]], adept in [[Upland rice]] cultivation, and having extensive tattoos and [[Stretching (body piercing)|stretched earlobes]] amongst both sexes.<ref>{{cite book|author=|title=Monthly Packet, Volume 12|year=1857|publisher=J. and C. Mozley|page=370|isbn=}}</ref>
==History== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Een Europeaan wordt op de oever van een rivier omringd door Kajan Dajak krijgers en bevolking tijdens een expeditie naar de berg Boekit Batoe op Serawak TMnr 60043369.jpg|thumb|left|A European man discussing with the leaders of the Kayan people in [[Sarawak]], circa 1900 to 1940.]] They may have originated from along the Kayan river in the [[North Kalimantan province]] of Borneo. They live along the upper Kayan and the middle [[Kapuas River|Kapuas]] and [[Mahakam River|Mahakam]] rivers.<ref name="TK8">{{cite book|author=Richard Ibuh|title=The Kayans|year=2014|publisher=Partridge Publishing Singapore|page=8|isbn=14-828-2683-6}}</ref> They seem to have expanded to the south in [[Sarawak]] in historic times, generating some conflicts with the [[Iban people|Iban]] that were expanding north at the same time.<ref name="TK8"/> They have settled in Sarawak on the middle [[Baram River]], the Bintulu River and along the [[Rajang River]],<ref name="TK8"/> having been pressed back a little during the late 19th century. In 1863 [[West Kalimantan]], [[Iban people]] migrated to the upstreams of Saribas River and [[Rejang River]] and started to attack the Kayan people in those areas and continued doing so northwards and later eastwards. Wars and headhunting attacks have caused many other tribes to be displaced, including the Kayan people, who make up of 1.4% of the [[West Kutai Regency]] population.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michaela Haug|title=Poverty and Decentralisation in East Kalimantan|year=2010|publisher=Centaurus Verlag & Media KG|isbn=9783825507701}}</ref> Significant expansion to the east Borneo also occurred during the historical times, the conversion of the Kayan people to [[Islam]] forming the [[ethnogenesis]] of the [[Sultanate of Bulungan|Bulungan people]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Anthony Milner|title=The Malays|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|page=|isbn=14-443-9166-6}}</ref>
==Language== The [[Kayan language (Borneo)|Kayan language]] belongs to the [[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] branch of the [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian language family]].<ref name="TK8"/>
==Main activities== [[File:Feuererzeugen bei den Kajan durch Reiben eines Strickes un ein Stück weichen, trockenen Holzes.jpg|thumb|left|A Kayan using [[rattan]] to "[[fire-saw|saw]]" a piece of firewood.]] Their basic culture is similar to the other [[Dayak people]] in [[Borneo]]. Their agriculture was based upon [[shifting cultivation]] techniques and the cultivation of [[Upland rice]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Jérôme Rousseau|title=Central Borneo: Ethnic Identity and Social Life in a Stratified Society|year=1990|publisher=Clarendon Press|page=134|isbn=01-982-7716-4}}</ref> Other farming such as [[sago]], corn, yams, pumpkin and tobacco are also cultivated. During the years of famine, sago is mined. Fishing (killing fish with poisons) plays an important role,<ref>{{cite book|author=Kathy MacKinnon & Gusti Hatta|title=Ecology of Kalimantan: Indonesian Borneo|year=2013|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|page=|isbn=14-629-0505-6}}</ref> and a smaller role is played by hunting with a ''[[Blowgun|sumpitan]]''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Odoardo Beccari; Enrico Hillyer Giglioli; F H H Guillemard|title=Wanderings In The Great Forests Of Borneo Travels And Researchers Of A Naturalist In Sarawak|year=1904|publisher=London, A. Constable & co., ltd.|page=264|oclc=933143659}}</ref> The Kayan people are engaged in breeding pigs and chickens, while dogs are kept for ritual purposes. The Kayan people are known as excellent blacksmiths (the Kayan [[Mandau (knife)|Mandau]] swords are the main item of exchange), boat builders and carpenters.<ref name="EGOISA170">{{cite book|author=Frank M. LeBar & George N. Appell|title=Ethnic Groups of Insular Southeast Asia: Indonesia, Andaman Islands, and Madagascar|year=1972|publisher=Human Relations Area Files Press|page=170|isbn=08-753-6403-9}}</ref> [[Loom]], weaving, production of tans, arts, wood carving, making of masks and pottery are also developed.<ref name="EGOISA170"/>
==Social structure== Traditionally, they live in [[long house]]s on river banks. Their settlement consists of one or several [[long house]]s as long as 300 meters, which can accommodate up to 100 families (400–600 people) and consist of a common veranda and rooms. Residents of a long house constitute a [[Tribe|tribal community]]. The Kayan people are divided into three [[endogamous]] caste-estate groups; "house owning group" or aristocrat (''ipun uma'' or ''keta'u''), community members or commoners (''panyun'') and slaves (''lupau'').<ref>{{cite book|contribution=Great Britain. Colonial Office|title=Colonial Research Studies, Issue 1|year=1950|publisher=H.M. Stationaery Office|page=72|isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor=David Levinson|title=Encyclopedia of World Cultures, Volume 5|year=1993|publisher=G.K. Hall|page=134|isbn=08-168-8840-X}}</ref> Among the nobility, marriages are usually outside of the community, often with other tribes; while community members and slaves usually marry within the community. The leader is usually elected from the nobility class (in the 19th century, he also served as a military leader). The settlement is bi-localized,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sabrizain.org/malaya/library/enc-sea.pdf |title=Encyclopedia of World Cultures, Volume V: East And Southeast Asia |editor=David Levinson |publisher=G.K. Hall & Company |page=134 |year=1993 |isbn=0-8168-8840-X |accessdate=2018-09-22}}</ref> and the filiation is bilateral,<ref>{{cite book|author=Souchou Yao|title=Confucian Capitalism: Discourse, Practice and the Myth of Chinese Enterprise|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|page=153|isbn=11-361-2794-1}}</ref> while the system of kinship is of the English model.
==Myth and religion== The Kayan people a developed mythology and a complex cult (bounty hunting and human sacrifices<ref>{{cite book|author=|title=Monthly Packet, Volume 12|year=1857|publisher=J. and C. Mozley|page=371|isbn=}}</ref> that disappeared at the beginning of the 20th century, as well as shamanism).<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert P. Gwinn|title=The New Encyclopaedia Britannica: Micropaedia, Holderness - Krasnoje, Volume 6|year=1987|publisher=Encyclopaedia Britannica|page=773|isbn=08-522-9434-4}}</ref> The core event was the feast of collected heads (''mamat''), during which warrior initiations and funeral ceremonies were held.<ref>{{cite book|author=Frank M. LeBar & George N. Appell|title=Ethnic Groups of Insular Southeast Asia: Indonesia, Andaman Islands, and Madagascar|year=1972|publisher=Human Relations Area Files Press|page=171-173|isbn=08-753-6403-9}}</ref> In the 20th century, the Kayan people began to convert to [[Christianity]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Peter Metcalf|title=The Life of the Longhouse: An Archaeology of Ethnicity|year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=190|isbn=11-394-8170-3}}</ref>
==Culture== ===Traditional Kayan song=== * Alam Lening (Dayak Kayaan Mendalam, Kalbar)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tjePa9i4Ins&feature=related |title=Alam Lening, lagu Dayak Kayaan Mendalam |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=26 September 2014}}</ref> * Lung Kayaan Mendalam<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YMQ3gjZAMmc&feature=related |title=Lung Kayaan |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=26 September 2014}}</ref>
== References == <references/>
== Further reading == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100222033103/http://www.tribalarts.com/feature/borneo/ Into the Art of Borneo: The Kenyah-Kayan Tradition] * [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/3307 The Pagan Tribes of Borneo by Charles Hose and William McDougall] from 1912.
