revision.comment: There was no lawsuit. References to "sued" in other sources have been misinterpreted to mean "lawsuit" instead of "appeal formally to a person for something." State law was passed in 1920 allowing women into publicly funded professional and graduate schools in VA. UVA added the stipulation that women must first complete at least two years of college elsewhere. Also edited the "graduated from." She only attended Sweet Briar for the two years required to enter UVA.) I am her daughter.
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Kitty O'Brien Joyner | image = Kitty Joyner - Electrical Engineer - GPN-2000-001933.jpg | image_size=300px | alt = | caption = Joyner analyzing the operation of a wind tunnel turbine at [[Langley Research Center|NACA Langley]] in 1952 | birth_date = {{birth date|1916|07|11}} | birth_place = [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] | birth_name = Kitty Wingfield O'Brien<ref>{{cite web |title=Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award Recipients |publisher=University of Virginia |url=https://vpsa.virginia.edu/awards/algernon |accessdate=2018-02-11}} O'Brien was one of three 1939 recipients.</ref> | death_date = {{death date and age|1993|08|16|1916|07|11}} | death_place = | monuments = | education = | alma_mater = {{ubl|[[Sweet Briar College]]|[[University of Virginia]]<ref name=obit />}} | occupation = [[Electrical engineer]] | years_active = 1939{{snd}}71 | employer = {{Flatlist| * [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics|NACA]] * [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration|NASA]]}} | organization = [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|IEEE]] | known_for = First woman engineer at the [[Langley Research Center|Memorial Langley Aeronautical Laboratory]] | spouse = Upshur T. Joyner | awards = [[Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award]] | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }}
'''Kitty O'Brien Joyner''' (July 11, 1916 – August 16, 1993) was an American [[electrical engineering|electrical engineer]] with the [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics]] (NACA), and then with the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) upon its replacement of NACA in 1958. She was hired in 1939 as the organization's first woman engineer, shortly after she had completed her degree as the first woman to graduate from the [[University of Virginia]]'s engineering program.
==Early life and education== Joyner was born in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. In 1937, women had not been admitted to the [[University of Virginia]] (UVA) Engineering School despite the 1920 state law allowing it.<ref>[http://voicesandvisibilityuva.org/about-these-portraits/women-at-uva-history/ "History of Women at UVA"]</ref> UVA added several admittance requirements for women; one that women must have completed at least two years of college elsewhere. Joyner petitioned the university to gain admission and was accepted after two years at [[Sweet Briar College]]. Two years later, in 1939, she became the first woman to graduate from the University of Virginia with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[electrical engineering]].<ref name=obit>{{cite web|work=Daily Press|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1993-08-20/news/9308200268_1_mrs-banks-senior-choir-kiwanis-club/2|title=Obituaries - Kitty Joyner|date=20 August 1993|last=Lineberry|first=Trivia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Local author spotlights under-the-radar female mathematicians at NASA |first=Joshua |last=Adams |date=December 23, 2016 |work=C-Ville |publisher= |url=http://www.c-ville.com/local-author-spotlights-radar-female-mathematicians-nasa/#.WoZbQ-jwY2w }}</ref> While at UVA, she received the [[Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award]] for excellence of character and service to humanity.<ref name=obit /><ref name=crgis>{{cite web|work=NASA CRGIS|title=Kitty O'Brien Joyner|publisher=NASA|url=http://crgis.ndc.nasa.gov/historic/Kitty_O'Brien_Joyner}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Kitty O'Brien Joyner - 1964-L-05210.jpg|thumb|upright|Joyner in 1964]] The [[NACA]] [[Langley Research Center|Langley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory]] (LMAL, later the Langley Research Center) hired Joyner as an electrical engineer in September 1939, making her their first woman engineer. Joyner worked for NACA/NASA for several decades, achieving the title Branch Head of the Facilities Cost Estimating Branch, Office of Engineering and Technical Services, and managing several [[wind tunnel]]s, including supersonic wind tunnels.<ref name=hatch>{{cite book|title=Changing Our World: True Stories of Women Engineers |last=Hatch |first=Sybil E. |publisher=ASCE Publications |date=2006 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dKptTDl6eUcC&pg=PA149 |location=Reston, VA |oclc=835993427 |isbn=9780784408353 |page=149}}</ref><ref name=crgis />
Joyner retired from NASA in May 1971.
Joyner was active in engineering organizations and societies. She was a member of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers]] and an Honorary Life Member of the Engineers Club of the Virginia Peninsula.<ref name=crgis />
==Personal life== Joyner's husband, Upshur T. Joyner, also worked at NACA/NASA Langley for 40 years as a physicist, retiring in 1971, the same year as Kitty.<ref name=crgis />
Joyner and her husband lived in [[Poquoson, Virginia]], and had two children, a son named Upshur, who died of leukemia at the age of 47 in 1990, and a daughter, Kate.<ref name=crgis />
Joyner died on August 16, 1993, at the age of 77. Her husband died a few months later, in November 1993, at the age of 85.<ref name=crgis /><ref name=obit />
In addition to her professional and personal engineering activities, she was also the first regent and organizer for the Charles Parish Chapter of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]], which named an annual scholarship after her.<ref>{{cite web|work=Daily Press|title=Faces/scholarships/degrees/honors|date=5 July 1989|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1989-07-05/news/8906300084_1_full-tuition-student-leaders-attend/2|}}</ref> She was also a recipient of the [[United Daughters of the Confederacy]] Winnie Davis Award.<ref name=obit />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *For additional details of Joyner's life, see {{cite web |title=Kitty Wingfield O'Brien |url=https://www.familysearch.org/tree/person/details/LBM4-6KR |publisher=FamilySearch |accessdate=2018-06-26 |registration=yes}} *{{Commons category-inline}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Joyner, Kitty}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:American electrical engineers]] [[Category:American women engineers]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:People from Charlottesville, Virginia]] [[Category:Sweet Briar College alumni]] [[Category:University of Virginia School of Engineering and Applied Science alumni]] [[Category:Engineers from Virginia]] [[Category:20th-century American engineers]] [[Category:20th-century women engineers]]

'''Lisa Brooks''' is an historian, writer, and professor of English and American studies at [[Amherst College]] in Massachusetts where she specializes in the history of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] and [[Europe]]an interactions from the American colonial period to the present.
Brooks is of [[Abenaki]] and [[Poles|Polish]] heritage<ref name="auto">Lisa Brooks, ''Our Beloved Kin'' (Yale University Press, 2018)</ref> and received her B.A. at [[Goddard College]] (1993) and her M.A. at [[Boston College]] (1995) and Ph.D. at the [[Cornell University]] (2004).<ref name="amherst.edu">{{cite web|url=https://www.amherst.edu/people/facstaff/lbrooks|title=Faculty & Staff - Brooks, Lisa - Amherst College|website=www.amherst.edu}}</ref> She is the author of many articles, essays and popular books including, ''The Common Pot: The Recovery of Native Space in the Northeast,'' (2008)<ref>The Common Pot — University of Minnesota Press, (2008) https://www.upress.umn.edu</ref> and ''Our Beloved Kin'' (2018).<ref name="auto"/> Brooks taught at [[Harvard University]] before moving to teach at [[Amherst College]]. Brooks teaches several classes on "Native American & Indigenous studies, early American literature, contemporary literature, and comparative American Studies"<ref name="amherst.edu"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.amherst.edu/people/facstaff/lbrooks Faculty page]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} :''For the fictional character on the TV Series, Sister, Sister, see [[Sister, Sister (TV series)|Sister, Sister]], (Section: Characters).''
'''Lisa Landry''' (born August 5) is an American [[comedian]], [[actress]] and writer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/aug/31/not-dirty-not-clean-her-routine-beige/ |title=Lisa Landry: Not dirty, not clean, her routine is 'beige' - Las Vegas Sun |work=lasvegassun.com |accessdate=August 31, 2009}}</ref>
==Early life== Lisa Landry grew up in [[Harvey, Louisiana|Harvey]], [[Louisiana]]. Her mother served in the [[United States Navy]] and was often stationed in other countries leaving Lisa and her little brother for months at a time to be raised by their father and grandparents. Landry is [[Cajun]] and dreamed of studying theater in New York and was so dedicated to getting into the [[American Musical and Dramatic Academy]] that she flew from [[New Orleans]] to [[Atlanta]] to audition for their acting program.
==Career==
Lisa Landry began her stand-up comedy career in the New York City comedy circuit where she honed her comedic skills in some of the very best venues in the country including [[Comedy Cellar]], [[Comic Strip Live]], and [[Gotham Comedy Club]]. It was in New York City where she met and married her husband. They divorced. While living in Manhattan, Lisa gave birth to a little boy, whom she named Ari Cajun Shapiro because she knew she'd made a Spicy Jew.
Lisa Landry starred in her own half-hour special ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]: Lisa Landry''<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsminer.com/features/latitude_65/comedian-lisa-landry-dishes-on-diets-divorce-and-dating-don/article_a8b0bcb6-b62e-11e3-88bb-0017a43b2370.html|title=Comedian Lisa Landry dishes on diets, divorce and dating dont's|work=Fairbanks Daily News-Miner|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> while pregnant with Ari. Immediately following birthing her special and birthing her child, Lisa appeared on [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]'s ''20 Greatest Redneck Moments''. Which got her featured in [[TV Guide]] as a "Top Pick" and also selected by [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] to appear in their "We Know Funny" commercials. Her special was chosen third by a nationwide vote in Comedy Central's "Standup Showdown" and she appeared on CBS's "[[The Late, Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]"<ref name="auto"/> where she received a standing ovation.
Landry was offered not one, but two residencies in Las Vegas. Landry headlined her own nightly show at [[Stratosphere Las Vegas|The Stratosphere]] when she was offered her own headline show at [[Planet Hollywood Las Vegas|Planet Hollywood]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vegasnews.com/155200/lisa-landry-joins-the-cast-of-sin-city-comedy-burlesque-at-planet-hollywood-resort-casino.html|title=Lisa Landry Joins the Cast of Sin City Comedy & Burlesque at Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino|work=Vegas News|accessdate=October 18, 2016}}</ref>
Lisa Landry has appeared on "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit|Law and Order: SVU]]", "[[Comics Unleashed]]", "Stand up in Stiletto's" (she wore cowgirl boots), [[E!|E!'s]] "Top 100 Celebrities", "[[Red Eye (TV series)]]", "[[The Bonnie Hunt Show]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.underthegunreview.net/2013/04/23/stand-up-tuesdays-lisa-landry/|title=STAND UP TUESDAYS: Lisa Landry - Under the Gun Review|work=Under the Gun Review|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> "[[The Bob & Tom Show]]", "The Steve and Preston Show", "Premium Blend", and recently co-hosted "[[WFSB#News operation|Better Connecticut]]". Landry was filmed for the "Vegas" episode of the [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] Series produced by [[Ellen DeGeneres]] called "Little Funny". The reality show about the eleven-year-old comedian [[Saffron Herndon]] was filmed but A&E decided not to air it. Landry was a performer on the [[Brett Butler (actress)|Brett Butler]]'s ''Southern Belles of Comedy DVD'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/lisa-landry-286223/credits/|title=Lisa Landry|work=TVGuide.com|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Landry was also a comedy writer for [[Us Weekly]]. Lisa Landry was offered the first ever talent holding deal with [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime Television]].
Landry's CD "Put Your Keys in the Keybowl" was selected as one of the Top Ten Best Comedy CD's on [[iTunes]] (2008). "Put Your Keys in the Keybowl" was also included that same year (2008) in the ''Top Ten Best'' by Punchline Magazine (since rebranded as LaughSpin) describes Landry best: "She's an incredibly skilled comedian, a controlling presence onstage and a master of pacing and delivery." Her follow-up project was the DVD "Brazillionaire". Landry has since released two more albums. Her comedy albums are enjoyed on various platforms throughout the planet including but not limited to iTunes, Amazon, Spotify, Pandora, Today's Comedy, SiriusXM Satellite Radio, and her official website.
Lisa Landry is now the host of her new podcast, WOMENACE to SOCIETY where she conducts socially relevant interviews of artists, activists, anarchists, dreamers, and doers from across America. The podcast can best be described as "Real People. Real Stories. Unreal World." Laughter Heals. Love One Another.

The following is a list of notable blind people. <!-- Previous version was deleted, in part, for poor or non-existent sourcing. Please do not add names without a valid source -->
== Activists and organizers of the blind == *[[Tilly Aston]] – Founder of the ''Victorian Association of Braille Writers.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womenaustralia.info/biogs/AWE2062b.htm|title=Aston, Matilda Ann - Woman - The Australian Women's Register|first=National Foundation for Australian Women and The University of|last=Melbourne|website=Womenaustralia.info|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Louis Braille]] – Known for [[Braille]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afb.org/braillebug/louis_braille_bio.asp|title=...Louis Braille Biography...|website=Afb.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Francis Joseph Campbell]] – Anti-slavery campaigner and co-founder of the [[Royal National College for the Blind]]<ref name="Palace">{{cite web|url= http://the-palace-mag.co.uk/history/lhrncollege.html|title= the royal normal college|publisher= The Palace|accessdate= 2008-11-24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> *[[Haben Girma]] – Disability rights advocate, first [[deafblind]] graduate of [[Harvard Law School]] *[[Kenneth Jernigan]] – Long-time leader of the [[National Federation of the Blind]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfb.org/nfb/About_the_Jernigan_Institute.asp?SnID=382141530 |title=Jernigan Institute |access-date=2008-06-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726115344/http://www.nfb.org/nfb/About_the_Jernigan_Institute.asp?SnID=382141530 |archive-date=2011-07-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Helen Keller]] – American deaf-blind writer, lecturer, and activist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afb.org/Section.asp?Sectionid=1|title=Helen Keller - American Foundation for the Blind|website=Afb.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Tiffany Brar]] – Social activist,who founded the Jyothirgamaya Foundation, which empowers the blind in all spheres of life *[[Juan Carlos González Leiva]] – Cuban lawyer, who founded the ''Fraternity of the Independent Blind of Cuba'' and ''the Cuban Foundation of Human Rights''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zyra.org.uk/leiva.htm|title=Cuba: blind political prisoner is in danger of losing life}}</ref> He has been harassed, imprisoned and tortured by the communist regime. *[[Sabriye Tenberken]] – [[Braille Without Borders]] co-founder.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/europe/hero2004/tenberken.html|title=Time Europe|website=Time.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> == Adventurers == *[[Miles Hilton-Barber]] – [[British people|British]] [[travel]]er and climber.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/programmes/outlook/news/story/2007/03/070307_blindpilot_uk.shtml|title=BBC World Service - Programmes - Outlook - Is this the world's most adventurous blind man?|website=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[James Holman]] – [[British people|British]] [[man]] known as the "Blind Traveler."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5675082|title=Tales of a Blind Traveler|website=Npr.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Tofiri Kibuuka]] – Ugandan-Norwegian athlete. One of the first three blind people to reach the summit of [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] (along with John Opio and Lawrence Sserwambala). First African competitor at the [[Winter Paralympic Games]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20120708183447/http://google.com/search?q=cache:5DuNTtWoGB0J:www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-21200052_ITM+%22Tofiri+Kibuuka%22+blind&cd=1&hl=fr&ct=clnk&gl=fr ]</ref><ref>[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/reports.html?type=participation&games=1976PWG&sport=all]{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref> *[[Takeichi Nishi]] – Colonel in the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] During World War II. Commander of the 26th Tank Regiment in the [[Battle of Iwo Jima]]. He was blinded during battle. *[[Erik Weihenmayer]] – First blind person to reach the summit of [[Mount Everest]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20010618,00.html|title=TIME Magazine Cover: Erik Weihenmayer - June 18, 2001|website=Time.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref>
== Artists == === Acting and performing === *[[Jack Birkett]] – also known as "Orlando" and "The Incredible Orlando"; camp actor, dancer, mime. Best known for his roles as Borgia Ginz in the [[Derek Jarman]] film ''[[Jubilee (1977 film)|Jubilee]]'', and as Caliban in Jarman's version of ''[[The Tempest (1979 film)|The Tempest]]''. Though his best-known and most prominent roles have been with Jarman, he has had roles in other films, including 1984's ''[[The Bride (1985 film)|The Bride]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088851/|title=The Bride|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> and in televised productions of [[Shakespeare]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0083584/|title=Jack Birkett|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Dana Elcar]] – Played [[Peter Thornton (MacGyver)]]. He lost his vision during this time and it was written into the character's story.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.macgyveronline.org/pages/dana2.html |title=Macgyver Online |access-date=2008-06-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051017223950/http://www.macgyveronline.org/pages/dana2.html |archive-date=2005-10-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[S. Robert Morgan]] – A recurring role in [[The Wire (TV series)|The Wire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/12/AR2005071201374.html|title=A Haven for Sightless Readers|first=Lindsay|last=Ryan|date=13 July 2005|accessdate=22 September 2018|website=Washingtonpost.com}}</ref> * [[Callan Mulvey]] – (an actor seen in various series as ''Rush'' and in movies like ''Batman Vs Superman'') has lost the sight by one eye during an accident. * [[Geraldine Lawhorn]] – one-woman show performer in [[New York City]].
=== Music === {{details|Blind musicians}} *[[Tsutomu Aragaki]], Japanese tenor, blind from just after birth.<ref>"[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fd20071216cs.html Comic child-detective, comedians visit the poor, blind singer docu-drama]." ''Japan Times'', December 6, 2007.</ref> *[[Garret Barry (piper)|Garret Barry]] - an Irish uilleann piper, among the most famous players of the 19th century.<ref>Davy Spillane, Tommy Walsh. 2011. ''The Davy Spillane Uilleann Pipe Tutor'', Book 1, Mel Bay Publications, March 31, 2011 p. 20</ref> *[[Delta Blind Billy]] - an American Delta blues artist and outlaw/<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ovguide.com/delta-blind-billy-9202a8c04000641f8000000014f59e9d# |title=Watch Delta Blind Billy Video |publisher=Ovguide.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> *[[Blind Blake]] - American blues and ragtime singer and guitarist.<ref name=gracyk>{{cite web|url=http://www.gracyk.com/blake1.shtml|title= The King of Ragtime Guitar: Blind Blake and His Piano-Sounding Guitar|author=Obrecht, Jas|publisher=Gracyk.com|accessdate=2014-09-02}}</ref> *[[The Blind Boys of Alabama]] – Gospel group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/10/21/60II/main526381.shtml|title=The Blind Boys Of Alabama|website=Cbsnews.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Andrea Bocelli]] – [[Operatic pop]] singer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/the-king-of-popera-20040828-gdjmr9.html|title=The king of popera|date=28 August 2004|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *Ricky Boon - Former guitarist of Australian [[thrash metal]] band [[Fury (band)|Fury]]. *[[Joséphine Boulay]] - French organist and composer.<ref>{{cite book |title="Une femme d'exception dans l'ombre de l'Institution Nationale des Jeunes Aveugles : Joséphine Boulay (1869-1925)", L'orgue, n° 255, III-2001, p. 7-20|first=Sébastien|last=Durand|year=2001}}</ref> *[[Rudolf Braun (composer)|Rudolf Braun]] – composer and organist. *[[Pearly Brown]] - American gospel blues singer and guitarist, known primarily as a street performer.<ref name=MeanOldWorld>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.co.uk/search?safe=off&hl=en&site=imghp&tbm=isch&source=hp&biw=1280&bih=618&q=pearly+brown&oq=pearly+brown&gs_l=img.3..0i30j0i5i30.4582.10738.0.11321.16.15.1.0.0.0.233.1968.0j9j2.11.0....0...1ac.1.64.img..5.11.1733.Py8oonOHv_o#imgrc=GbSQ3anD2fb4XM%3A |first=Jim Jr. |last=Pettigrew |title=Liner notes to the LP ''It's a Mean Old World to Try to Live in |accessdate=August 30, 2015 }}</ref> *[[Blind James Campbell]] - === Writers === *[[Homer]] – Ancient Greek orator of the epic poems ''Iliad'' and ''Odyssey''. According to legend, he was blind either at birth or due to disease or injury. *[[Jorge Luis Borges]] – Argentine writer blind in later part of his career.<ref>[http://www.themodernword.com/borges/borges_biography.html The Modern Word] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509185921/http://www.themodernword.com/borges/borges_biography.html |date=2008-05-09 }}</ref> *[[Didymus the Blind]] – Ecclesiastical writer of Alexandria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04784a.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Didymus the Blind|website=Newadvent.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Belo Cipriani]] – Latino writer, blind at the age of 26. *[[Ed Lucas]] – Sports writer.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/18/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/18NJCol.html?_r=2&ex=1175140800&en=16a1c76f6d2e2a58&ei=5070&oref=slogin&oref=slogin|title=Baseball Stole His Eyes, but Not His Passion|first=Kevin|last=Coyne|website=Nytimes.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[John Milton]] – Poet who was blind for the last 22 years of life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christs.cam.ac.uk/milton400/life.htm |title=Christ's College, Cambridge |access-date=2008-06-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305004047/http://www.christs.cam.ac.uk/milton400/life.htm |archive-date=2010-03-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Helen Keller]] – American writer who was both blind and deaf. *[[Ved Mehta]] – an Indian/American writer who was born in [[Lahore]] (now a Pakistani city) to a Hindu family. *[[Nikolai Ostrovsky]] – a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[socialist realist]] writer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sovlit.net/rememberingostrovsky/|title=SovLit.net - Remembering Nikolai Ostrovsky|website=Sovlit.net|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Aldous Huxley]] – British philosophical writer, partially blind. *[[Taha Hussein]] – Egyptian writer and intellectual who became blind at the age of three. *[[Jack Vance]] – highly prolific American master of fantasy.

== Engineers == *[[John Metcalf (civil engineer)|John Metcalf]] *[[T. V. Raman]]
== Mathematicians and scientists == *[[Jacob Bolotin]] – the world's first totally blind physician fully licensed to practice medicine. *[[Gustaf Dalén]] – [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[inventor]] and Nobel Prize winner, who continued to make inventions and lead his company despite being blinded in an accident. *[[Leonhard Euler]] – Swiss mathematician and physicist who went almost totally blind at fifty-nine, but his productivity on mathematics did not decrease throughout his life. *[[François Huber]] – Swiss naturalist who made fundamental contributions to melittology. *[[Bernard Morin]] – topologist from France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200210/comm-morin.pdf|format=PDF|title=The World of Blind Mathematicians|website=Ams.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Abraham Nemeth]] – Developed [[Nemeth Braille]] for blind students in science and math.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfb.org/Images/nfb/Publications/bm/bm06/bm0608/bm060805.htm|title=Awards Presented at the 2006 Convention of the National Federation of the Blind|website=Nfb.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Joseph Plateau]] – Physicist who went blind at forty-two when he gazed too long at the sun. After his blindness his scientific work diminished, but did not entirely end.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/16067b.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Joseph-Antoine Plateau|website=Newadvent.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Lev Pontryagin]] – [[Soviet]] [[mathematician]] who went blind at fourteen. He continued mathematical study with the help of his mother Tatyana Andreevna, and made major discoveries in a number of fields of mathematics. *[[Nicholas Saunderson]] – English mathematician who went blind at the age of twelve months, held in high esteem by [[Isaac Newton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rnib.org.uk/xpedio/groups/public/documents/visugate/public_histedbl.hcsp|title=Our history|date=24 February 2014|website=Rnib.org.uk|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref>
== Medical professionals == *[[Satish Amarnath|Dr. Satish Amarnath]] – an Indian Medical Microbiologist who became totally blind after an acid attack.
== Politicians == *[[Abdurrahman Wahid]] – otherwise known as Gusdur – former president of Indonesia. *[[Richard H. Bernstein]] – Elected to [[Wayne State University]] Board of Governors in Michigan. *[[David Blunkett]] – [[Labour Party (UK)]] politician, former cabinet minister, and [[Member of Parliament]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/oct/07/comment.politics4|title=Interview: David Blunkett|first1=Patrick|last1=Wintour|first2=Julian|last2=Glover|date=7 October 2006|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Kristen Cox]] – Cabinet secretary in [[Utah]] and [[Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,640193209,00.html|title=Blind ex-Utahn on ballot|date=8 July 2006|website=Deseretnews.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Matthew A. Dunn]] – Member of the [[United States House of Representatives]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=D000551|title=DUNN, Matthew Anthony - Biographical Information|website=Bioguide.congress.gov|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Henry Fawcett]] – [[Member of Parliament]] and [[Postmaster General of the United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/biography/?id=WH1038&type=P|title=University of Glasgow :: Story :: Biography of Henry Fawcett|website=Universitystory.gla.ac.uk|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Ian Fraser, Baron Fraser of Lonsdale]] – [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[St Pancras North (UK Parliament constituency)|St Pancras North]] for eleven non-consecutive years, blinded in World War I.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lordfraser.co.za/londsdale_information.htm |title=Fraser Company Fact sheet |access-date=2009-02-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061002110524/http://www.lordfraser.co.za/londsdale_information.htm |archive-date=2006-10-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Thomas Gore]] – [[United States Senate|US Senator]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=G000323|title=GORE, Thomas Pryor - Biographical Information|website=bioguide.congress.gov|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Cyrus Habib]] – 16th [[Lieutenant Governor of Washington]]. *[[Louis the Blind]] – 10th century European king, blinded after being captured. *[[Colin Low, Baron Low of Dalston]] – Member of the British House of Lords. *[[Floyd Morris]], [[List of Presidents of the Senate of Jamaica|President of the Senate of Jamaica]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/SShould-a-blind-man-be-named-Senate-President-_14296628|title=Should a blind man be named Senate President?|first=Jamaica Observer|last=Limited|website=Jamaica Observer|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130523/news/news1.html|title=All eyes on newly appointed senate president Floyd Morris|website=jamaica-gleaner.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[David Paterson]] – Governor of New York.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/14/first-legally-blind-governor-not-quite/index.html |title=The New York Times blog |access-date=2008-06-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531093910/http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/14/first-legally-blind-governor-not-quite/index.html |archive-date=2008-05-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Bob C. Riley]] – An acting governor of Arkansas.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> *[[Thomas D. Schall]] – A US Senator from Minnesota, blinded by an electrical shock before his time in office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=S000113|title=SCHALL, Thomas David - Biographical Information|website=bioguide.congress.gov|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> * [[Vasily II of Russia]], the 15th century Grand Prince of Moscow * [[Béla II of Hungary|Béla the Blind]], the 12th century King of Hungary * [[Enrico Dandolo]], 12th and 13th century 42nd Doge of Venice
=== Political activists === *[[Shelley Davis]] – American lawyer and labor advocate. *[[Chen Guangcheng]] – Lawyer and [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] winner was imprisoned in China on 22 April 2012, Chen escaped from house arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa17/022/2007/en/|title=Amnesty International|website=Amnesty.org|accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> *[[Jacques Lusseyran]] – French author and political activist during World War II.<ref>[http://www.holocaust-trc.org/faces.htm#jacques Stories of the teenage resistance], Holocaust Education Foundation, retrieved on 15 December 2008.</ref>
== Saints == *[[Didymus the Blind]] - Dean of the Theological School of Alexandria and first man to memorise the [[Holy Bible]] *[[Lutgardis]] – Catholic saint, blind in the last 11 years of her life. *[[Pacificus of San Severino]] - [[Franciscan]] visionary. *[[Surdas]] – Hindu saint, devotional poet and singer who lived during reign of king Akbar (1542–1606).
== Diplomats == *[[Beno Zephine N L]] – Indian Foreign Service officer.
== Others == *[[Mary Ingalls]] – sister of Laura Ingalls Wilder, author. *[[Gary O'Donoghue]] – political correspondent for the [[BBC]]. *[[Ed Walker (radio personality)|Ed Walker]] – lifelong radio show host/humorist, Washington, DC. *[[Akbar Khan (disability activist)|Akbar Khan]] – Singer, Composer, Writer and a Banker honored with National Award in 1989, [[Rajasthan]], [[India]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akbarkhan.co.in|title=Information website about Akbar Khan, Bikaner, Rajasthan, India|website=Akbarkhan.co.in}}</ref> *[[Ashish Goyal]] – first blind trader in finance.
== Fictional == {{See also|:Category:Fictional blind characters|l1=Fictional blind characters}} *[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]] – Blind [[Marvel Comics]] [[superhero]] *[[Geordi La Forge]] was blind since birth, but uses a [[VISOR]] and later ocular implants that allow him to see the [[electromagnetic spectrum]]. The character was created by [[Gene Roddenberry]] as a positive role model for the disabled. *[[Toph Beifong]] from the show ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' was born blind, but uses her Earthbending abilities to sense vibrations and "see" things that are in contact with the earth. For this reason, she hates flying and sailing, as she lacks contact with the ground and is truly blind. *[[Tommy (album)|Tommy]], the titular character of an album by [[The Who]]. His blindness, along with his [[deafness]] and [[muteness]], are actually [[psychosomatic]]. *Phillip Enright – Main character of ''[[The Cay]]'' who becomes temporarily blind due to a concussion. *[[Jerec]] was a ''Star Wars'' character who served [[Emperor Palpatine]] as an Inquisitor. A [[Miraluka]], he was born without eyes. *[[List of Star Wars characters#Tahl|Tahl]], a love interest of [[Qui-Gon Jinn]], was rendered blind after being held captive. However, with the use of the Force, she was able to compensate for her blindness. *Halcyon "Hal" Green, a character from the short story "[[The Demigod Diaries|The Diary of Luke Castellan]]" of the ''[[Percy Jackson & the Olympians]]'' series, was a blind seer who antagonist [[Luke Castellan]] befriended long before his fall from grace. *Master Po from the ''[[Kung Fu (TV series)|Kung Fu]]'' TV series. *Garrett from ''[[Quest for Camelot]]'', a love interest of Kayley, was rendered blind after being struck accidentally by a horse during a stable fire. But uses his skills he learnt from Ayden, a silver-winged falcon, to survive whilst living in the Forbidden Forest.

{{Infobox model | name = Magdalena Graaf | image = Magdalena Graaf.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Engla Maria Magdalena Graaf | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|9|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]] | height = {{height|m=1.69|precision=0}} | haircolor = [[Blond]]e | eyecolor = [[Eye color#Blue|Blue]] | measurements = | weight = | dress size = | shoesize = | website = [http://www.magdalenagraaf.se/ Official Site] | spouse = {{marriage|Unknown|1995|1996}}
{{marriage|[[Magnus Hedman]]|1999|2007}} }} '''Engla Maria Magdalena Graaf''' (born 2 September 1975 in [[Gothenburg]]) is a [[Swedish people|Swedish]] [[model (person)|model]], [[singer]], and [[author]]. In 1998, she and her sister [[Hannah Graaf|Hannah]] joined together and formed the group [[The Graaf Sisters]], who became popular with the song "You Got What I Want Baby". She was also the wife of [[association football|footballer]] [[Magnus Hedman]] and as a result has been voted the sexiest footballer's wife.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006210542/http://www.nordinagency.se/?id=423&type=fiction|title=Nordin Agency - Graaf, Magdalena|date=2011-10-06|access-date=2018-06-05}} ==Early years== Graaf was born in [[Gothenburg]], but she grew up in [[Kungsängen]] in [[Stockholm County]], to [[Pentecostalism|Swedish Pentecostal]] parents. In her late teens, Graaf became pregnant with her son Isak. Instead of burdening or embarrassing her religious parents, she married her Finnish gangster boyfriend Jorma whom she was already living with. During this time, she was physically and emotional abused.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/wendela/article361558.ab |title="Jag flydde med min son i famnen" - Wendela - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.magdalenagraaf.nu/ |title=magdalenagraaf.nu |publisher=magdalenagraaf.nu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206080600/http://www.magdalenagraaf.nu/ |archivedate=February 6, 2012 }} After Graaf was shot in the leg, she left her husband despite threats against her and her family. She eventually reported him to the proper authorities. As a result, she was placed under protective custody and given new identities.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article361032.ab |title=Hon sköts med pistol - Nyheter - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date=2006-03-14 |accessdate=2012-09-28}} She and her son were moved throughout Sweden but eventually settled in [[Gothenburg]] and was given the new names of Michaela and Ville for her son.{{cite book| title= Det ska bli ett sant nöje att döda dej| author = Magdalena Graaf | publisher=Bokförlaget Lind & Co AB | year = 2006 | isbn= 978-91-85267-66-8}} Her husband was eventually released from prison and he put a 50 000 SEK bounty on her and a reward for hurting her sister model, [[Hannah Graaf|Hannah]]. After her husband's indictment, the police did little to help Graaf. She did receive some help from a policewoman who would eventually get fired for helping Graaf. To this day, Graaf has a bitter disdain for the Swedish authorities. Her plight eventually was heard by former MC gang leader who felt bad for her and decided to protect Graaf. Finally, Graaf had enough of hiding and returned home to her mother. Later her ex-husband decided to stop the harassment. ==Career== === Modeling === Due to all the stress following the aftermath her ex-husband's indictment, Graaf lost a great deal of weight and suffered from lack of confidence. She underwent [[breast augmentation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sofismode/article48596.ab |title=Kändisarna som valt operation - Sofis mode - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date=2001-12-11 |accessdate=2012-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216124655/http://www.aftonbladet.se/sofismode/article48596.ab |archivedate=December 16, 2010 }} and started an exercise regimen. Her sister Hannah, an established model, took her to a celebrity party where she met [[E-Type (musician)|E-Type]] who hit on her. She claims this boosted her confidence and being seen on the party scene with her sister landed her a modeling career. Graaf followed the footsteps of her younger sister and began glamour modeling. Graaf would often model with her sister Hannah. The two gained noterity for appearing in countless men's magazines. The controversy catapulted lesser known Graaf's career. She has appeared in the magazines ''[[Café Magazine|Café]]'', ''[[Moore Magazine|Moore]]'', and ''[[Slitz]]''. In 1998, Graaf appeared on three separate'' Café ''covers. In 2004, The Graaf were looking for a comeback. The sisters flew to [[Los Angeles]] and did a pictorial for ''[[FHM]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.expressen.se/1.215471 |title=Systrarna Graaf gör comeback - Nöje - Expressen Nöje - Nöjesnyheter Musiknyheter Filmnyheter |publisher=Expressen.se |date=2005-06-09 |accessdate=2012-09-28}} ===Music=== The Graaf sisters became a cultural phenomenon and, by 1998 both sisters gave up glamour modeling to pursue a music career. That same year, she formed a musical duo [[The Graaf Sisters]] with Hannah and was quickly signed to [[Sony BMG]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/noje/9807/30/graaf.html |title=Aftonbladet nöje: Graafs debutlåt på singeltoppen |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}} The two worked with producers [[Christer Sandelin]], Tommy Ekman, and Rob 'n' Raz. The record yielded the Swedish #1 hit "You Got (What I Want)". The duo has since been on hiatus with both women marrying and having children. In 2002, the sisters were involved in a civil suit against [[Mikael Brinkstierna]]. Brinkstierna alleged that the sisters began working with him in 1996 and that they had a management contract in which he was entitled to 25% of all revenues from the sisters' future disc sales. After the success of their first album, Brinkstierna received no money after he allegedly spent hours helping them be a success. The sisters claim that Brinkstierna gave them nothing but money and accused him of being a crook after a similar dispute Brinkstierna had with the pop group [[Aqua (band)|Aqua]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/musik/article99592.ab |title=Miljonkrav mot systrarna Graaf - Musik - Nöjesbladet - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date=2002-10-12 |accessdate=2012-09-28}} ===Author=== In March 2006, Graaf released her biography ''Det ska bli ett sant nöje att döda dig'' ("It is going to be a true pleasure to kill you"), where she tells about her childhood and her first, problematic marriage. The title of her book was the last thing her ex-husband Jorma said to her before she left him and fled with their son Isak. ===Television=== Graaf participated in the Swedish edition of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'' (''Let's Dance'') until the end of January 2009, when she was forced to quit due to a [[cerebral hemorrhage]].{{cite web|url=http://www.expressen.se/noje/1.1446757/magdalena-graaf-akut-till-sjukhus-efter-blodning-i-hjarnan|title=Magdalena Graaf akut till sjukhus efter blödning i hjärnan|accessdate=2009-01-28|publisher=Expressen|author=Kai-Anders Nilsson|language=sv}} She also works for Postkodlotteriet and gives the winners money, Postkodsmiljonären where the main show is broadcast on [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]]. ==Personal life== In 1995, she gave birth to her first son, Isak, with her first husband. A year and a half after Isak's birth, Graaf left her husband in 1996. In 1999, Graaf married Swedish football goalkeeper [[Magnus Hedman]]. The couple had two sons named Lancelot (born in 2000) and Tristan (born in 2004). During their early marriage, the couple lived in [[Scotland]] where Hedman was playing soccer in [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1402247/bio|title=Magdalena Graaf|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2012-09-28}} After Hedman's retirement the couple resided in Stockholm. In 2006, Graaf separated from Hedman after news papers reported an alleged affair with singer [[Linda Bengtzing]].{{cite web|author=Se hela veckans tv-tablå på |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/klick/article437589.ab |title="Hon är en wannabe" - Klick! - Nöjesbladet - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date=2006-09-15 |accessdate=2012-09-28}} The couple have since divorced. Her fourth son, Charlie, was born in 2011. Her oldest son Isak died in an accident on August 25, 2014. {{Cite web|url=http://magdalenagraaf.se/|title=Magdalena Graafs blogg|last=blogg|first=Magdalena Graafs|website=magdalenagraaf.se|language=sv-SE|access-date=2018-06-05}} She gave birth to her fifth son Louie in 2016. ==Charity== The Sisters made [[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]]'s List of European Heroes for their charity work. Magdalena along with Hannah have donated earnings from their modeling to aid [[orphanage]]s in [[Nagpur]] in central [[India]]. The sisters maintain that they never have strayed too far from their Pentecostal upbringing and that their commitment for charity was inherited from their mother Linda Bergling who worked as a [[missionary]] in Asia and Africa. Not only have the donated money to the cause but they have built two orphanages and school. Magdelena's then husband, Magnus claimed Magdalena would constantly hits up friends for donations at parties.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article135000.ab |title=Systrarna Graaf - svenska hjältar - Nyheter - Aftonbladet |publisher=Aftonbladet.se |date=2003-04-20 |accessdate=2012-09-28}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.magdalenagraaf.se/ Official website] *{{sv icon}} [http://www.aftonbladet.se/noje/9807/30/graaf.html Article about the Graaf sisters success] *{{sv icon}} [http://www.aftonbladet.se/vss/kvinna/story/0,2789,793663,00.html Graaf speaking about her book] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Graaf, Magdalena}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Upplands-Bro Municipality]] [[Category:Swedish female models]] [[Category:Swedish pop singers]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Swedish women writers]] [[Category:Women biographers]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Malaika Griffin | image_name = Malaika Tamu Griffin.png | image_size = | image_caption = Colorado Department of Corrections mugshot | birth_name = Malaika Tamu Griffin | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1971|05|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | alias = Lake Griffin | motive = | charge = | conviction = First-degree murder, Aggravated robbery, Aggravated motor vehicle theft | conviction_penalty = Life in prison | conviction_status = Imprisoned at [[LaVista Correctional Facility]] in [[Pueblo, Colorado]] | occupation = [[Biochemist]] | spouse = | parents = Alice Griffin (mother) | children = }}
'''Malaika Tamu Griffin''' (born May 11, 1971) is an [[United States|American]] woman serving a life sentence at the LaVista Correctional Facility in [[Pueblo, Colorado]] for shooting her neighbor Jason Patrick Horsley to death in May 1999. After the shooting, Griffin became a fugitive from justice for six years, but after she was profiled on ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'', Griffin was captured in [[El Cajon, California]], a suburb of [[San Diego]], in June 2005.<ref name="Woman">{{cite news|title=Woman Arrested in 1999 Denver Slaying|publisher=Denver News|date=2005-06-07|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/4578641/detail.html}}</ref>
==Background== Malaika Tamu Griffin was born on May 11, 1971.<ref name=Griffin>{{cite news|title=Griffin, Malaika|publisher=Colorado Department of Corrections|year=2011|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://www.doc.state.co.us/oss/}}</ref> She graduated [[magna cum laude]] from [[Jackson State University]] and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in chemistry. Griffin was known to be a 'loner', and after her [[graduation]] from JSU, she went on a solo backpacking journey in Europe. In 1999, she moved to [[Denver, Colorado]], where she was working in a pharmacy and was renting a room in a house next door to a white couple: Jason Patrick Horsley and his girlfriend Deborah Loiselle. Jason Horsley was a carpenter, and Griffin became angry when Horsley laid his tools on the sidewalk in front of her house after work. A bitter argument ensued on May 18, 1999.<ref name="Black">{{cite news|title=Black Female Terrorist-Undercover?|publisher=Panache Report|year=2011|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://panachereport.com/channels/hip%20hop%20gallery/HipHopShortStories/Blk%20Terror.htm}}</ref>
==Crime== After arguing with Jason Horsley on May 18, 1999, Griffin returned to her apartment and came out with a 9 mm handgun with a laser sight and shot Horsley point blank in the back, killing him instantly.<ref name="Trial">{{cite news|title=Trial Begins For Woman Profiled On 'America's Most Wanted'|publisher=Denver News|date=2006-02-27|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/7498160/detail.html}}</ref> Immediately after the incident, Griffin fled to the nearby home of an acquaintance, Monique Thomas. Griffin stole Thomas' car at gunpoint and then drove away. The car was later found abandoned in [[Iowa City, Iowa]].<ref name="Woman"/>
Inside Malaika Griffin's apartment, police found a 9 mm carbine, ammunition, hand grenades and the library of a terrorist, with books about terrorism and bomb making including ''[[The Anarchist Cookbook]]'', ''Home Workshop Silencers'' and ''[[The Poor Man's James Bond]]''. In addition, Griffin's diary was also discovered. In it, Griffin expresses her deep hatred for white people.<ref name="Black"/>
==Fugitive years and capture== Griffin had last been seen boarding a bus to [[Chicago, Illinois]]. After that, there had been no sighting of her for years.<ref name="Black"/> On May 22, 2004, more than five years after the murder, Griffin was profiled again on ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'', and then again a year later on June 4, 2005. After the second showing, authorities received a tip from Griffin's co-workers.<ref name="Malaika Tamu">{{cite news|title=Malaika Tamu Griffin|publisher=America's Most Wanted|year=2011|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212121345/http://www.amw.com:80/fugitives/case.cfm?id=24797}}</ref> The [[FBI]] and the [[El Cajon Police Department]] contacted the suspect, who had been going by the name "Lake Griffin." After the FBI confronted her, Griffin admitted her identity.<ref name="Black"/> She had been working at a biotech firm as a lab assistant, at a fast-food restaurant and thrift store.<ref name="Woman"/> Griffin was charged with first-degree murder, aggravated robbery, and aggravated motor vehicle theft. She waived her extradition and was returned to Colorado to stand trial.<ref name="Malaika Tamu"/>
==Trial== Griffin's trial began on February 27, 2006.<ref name="Trial"/> Prosecutors also entered into evidence the weapons found in Griffin's apartment after she fled. Griffin decided to testify in her own defense at the trial. She claimed to be innocent of the offenses, and said her diary was about a play she was writing. After a one-week-long trial and seven hours of jury deliberations, Malaika Griffin was convicted on all counts.<ref name="America's">{{cite news|title='America's Most Wanted' Female Fugitive Guilty Of Murder|work=Denver News|date=2006-03-06|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/7756412/detail.html}}</ref> Under Colorado law, a [[first-degree murder]] conviction results in an automatic sentence of [[life in prison without parole]].
==Aftermath== Griffin's case was profiled on the [[Oxygen Network]] program ''[[Snapped]]'' on February 3, 2008 and on [[Investigation Discovery]]'s ''[[Deadly Women]]'' on October 12, 2012.
Griffin filed an appeal in April 2009 to the [[Colorado Court of Appeals]]. She argued that her convictions should be overturned because her trial [[Lawyer|attorney]] was not licensed to practice law in Colorado, her notebook entries, self-defense instructions, and [[prosecutorial misconduct]]. All of her claims were denied, and her convictions were all affirmed on April 16, 2009.<ref name="Colorado">{{cite news|title=Colorado Court of Appeals -- April 16, 2009 No. 06CA0784. People v. Griffin|publisher=Colorado Bar Association|date=2009-04-16|accessdate=2011-05-17|url=http://www.cobar.org/opinions/opinion.cfm?opinionid=7103&courtid=1}}</ref>

{{Infobox spree killer | name=Marc Sappington | birthname=Marc Vincent Sappington | alias='''The Kansas City Vampire''' | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1978|2|9}} | birth_place= | death_date= | cause= | date= March 16-April 10, 2001 | fatalities=4 | weapons = Knives and guns | country=United States | states=[[Kansas]] | sentence=[[Life imprisonment|Life]] | motive = [[Schizophrenia]] |image=Marc Sappington.jpg}} '''Marc Vincent Sappington''' (born February 9, 1978) is an American [[spree killer]] convicted of murdering four acquaintances in March and April 2001 in [[Kansas City, Kansas]].<ref name=APDraper>{{cite news |last=Draper |first=Bill |publisher=Associated Press |date=23 July 2004 |title=Man suspected of eating victim convicted of three murders counts}}</ref><ref name=AP04Dec10>{{cite news |author=(no byline) |publisher=Associated Press |date=10 December 2004 |title=Another life sentence for Kansas man convicted in four murders}}</ref> He gained notoriety for eating part of the leg of one of his victims, Alton "Fred" Brown.<ref name=StuffMag>{{cite news |last= McGraw |first= Seamus |publisher= Stuff Magazine |date= 13 August 2004 |title= Friends for Dinner |url= http://www.stuffmagazine.com/articles/index.aspx?id=799 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070929131559/http://www.stuffmagazine.com/articles/index.aspx?id=799 |archivedate= 29 September 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Lawyers for Sappington blamed the four-day killing spree on a history of [[schizophrenia]] and daily use of the [[hallucinogen]]ic drug [[Phencyclidine|PCP]]. Sappington himself claimed that voices in his head told him to eat flesh and blood or he would die.<ref name=APDraper />
Sappington was convicted on June 23, 2004 of murdering Terry T. Green, 25, Michael Weaver Jr., 22, and Alton "Fred" Brown Jr., 16 in April 2001.<ref name=APDraper /> Sappington was convicted on December 10, 2004 of an attempted [[aggravated robbery]] and murder of David Mashak at his auto dealership in March 2001.<ref name=AP04Dec10 /> Sappington's conviction was affirmed by the Kansas Supreme Court on November 2, 2007.
In an April 2001 videotape, Sappington had confessed to stabbing Weaver to death, leaving Green's body in a car, and shooting Brown before dismembering his body and eating a small piece of his leg.<ref name=APDraper />

Sappington] *[http://www.kscourts.org/Cases-and-Opinions/opinions/supct/2007/20071102/94415.htm State v. Sappington]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | Name = Mehran Karimi Nasseri | image = MKNasseri.jpg | imagesize = 255px | birth_name = '''مهران کریمی ناصری'''
Mehran Karimi Nasseri | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1942}} | birth_place = [[Masjed Soleiman]], [[Pahlavi dynasty|Iran]] | nationality = [[Iran]]ian (1942–1977)
[[Statelessness|Stateless]] (1977–present) }} '''Mehran Karimi Nasseri''' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: مهران کریمی ناصری pronounced {{IPA-fa|mehˈrɒn kʲæriˈmi nɒseˈri|}}; born 1942), also known as '''Sir, Alfred Mehran''',{{cite web |accessdate = 2 September 2009 |url = http://www.snopes.com/travel/airline/airport.asp |title = Stranded at the Airport |work = [[Snopes]] |date = 2 July 2008 }} is an [[Iran]]ian [[refugee]] who lived in the departure lounge of Terminal One in [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]] from 26 August 1988 until July 2006, when he was hospitalized for an unspecified ailment. His autobiography has been published as a book, ''The Terminal Man'', in 2004. His story was the inspiration for the 2004 [[Steven Spielberg]] film ''[[The Terminal]]''. ==Early life== Nasseri was born in the [[Anglo-Persian Oil Company]] settlement located in [[Masjed Soleiman]], Iran. His father was an Iranian doctor working for the company. Nasseri stated that his mother was a nurse from [[Scotland]] working in the same place. He arrived in the [[United Kingdom]] in September 1973, to take a three-year course in [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] studies at the [[University of Bradford]]. == Life in Terminal 1 == [[File:Merhan Karimi Nasseri Walkway Look 2005-12-30 01.jpg|thumb|300px|Nasseri's residency site in Terminal 1 of [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]].]] Nasseri claims he was expelled from Iran in 1977 for protests against the [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah]] and after a long battle, involving applications in several countries, was awarded refugee status by the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] in [[Belgium]]. This allegedly permitted residence in many other European countries. However, this claim has been disputed, with investigations showing that Nasseri was never expelled from Iran.{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/sep/06/features.features11 |title = The man who lost his past |date = 6 September 2004 |last = Berczeller |first = Paul |accessdate = 1 August 2008 |work= [[The Guardian]] |location = London }} Having claimed to have one British parent, although he has produced no evidence to support this claim, he decided to settle in the UK in 1986, but en route there in 1988, his papers were lost when his briefcase was allegedly stolen{{cite web |accessdate = 20 August 2008 |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A33471100 |title = Mehran Karimi Nasseri - In Transit |work = [[h2g2]] |publisher = BBC |date = 28 May 2008 }} (others indicate that Nasseri actually mailed his documents to Brussels while onboard a ferry to Britain, lying about them being stolen).{{cite book |publisher = Corgi Adult |isbn = 9780552152747 |title = The Terminal Man |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL7815505M/The_Terminal_Man |first = Alfred |last = Merhan |date = 2004 |id = 0552152749 }} Despite this setback, he boarded the plane for [[London]] but was promptly returned to France when he failed to present a passport to British immigration officials. He was initially arrested by the French, but then released as his entry to the airport was legal and he had no country of origin to be returned to; thus began his residency at Terminal 1. His case was later taken on by French human rights lawyer Christian Bourget. In 1992, a French court ruled that, having entered the country legally, he could not be expelled from the airport, but it could not grant him permission to enter France. Attempts were then made to have new documents issued from Belgium, but the authorities there would only do so if Nasseri presented himself in person. However, under Belgian law a refugee who voluntarily leaves a country that has accepted him cannot return. In 1995, the Belgian authorities granted permission for him to return, but only if he agreed to live there under supervision of a social worker. Nasseri refused this on the grounds of wanting to enter the UK as originally intended. Both France and Belgium offered Nasseri residency, but Nasseri refused to sign the papers as they listed him as being Iranian (he wanted it to be British) and did not show his preferred name, "Sir, Alfred Mehran". His refusal to sign the documents that would give him his freedom was much to the frustration of his lawyer, Bourget. When contacted about Nasseri's situation, his family stated that they believed he was living the life he wanted. In 2003 Spielberg's [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]] production company paid US$250,000 to Nasseri for the rights to his story, but ultimately did not use his story in the subsequent film, ''[[The Terminal]]''. Nasseri's stay at the airport ended in July 2006 when he was hospitalized and his sitting place dismantled. Towards the end of January 2007 he left the hospital and was looked after by the airport's branch of the [[French Red Cross]]; he was lodged for a few weeks in a hotel close to the airport. On 6 March 2007 he transferred to an [[Emmaus (charity)|Emmaus charity]] reception-centre in [[Paris]]'s [[20th arrondissement of Paris|20th arrondissement]]. Since 2008 he has continued to live in a Paris shelter. During his 18-year-long stay at Terminal 1 in the Charles de Gaulle Airport, Nasseri had his luggage at his side and spent his time reading, writing in his diary or studying economics.{{cite web |url = http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/1347/has-a-guy-been-stuck-in-the-paris-airport-since-1988-for-lack-of-the-right-papers |title = Has a guy been stuck in the Paris airport since 1988 for lack of the right papers? |last1 = Adams |first1 = Cecil |date = 20 August 1999 |website = [[The Straight Dope]] |publisher = |access-date = |quote = }} He received food and newspapers from employees of the airport, visits from journalists eager to hear his story and letters of support. == Autobiography == In 2004 Nasseri's autobiography, ''The Terminal Man'', was published. It was co-written by Nasseri with British author Andrew Donkin and was reviewed in '' [[The Sunday Times]]'' as being "profoundly disturbing and brilliant".{{Cite news |url = https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/memoir-the-terminal-man-by-sir-alfred-mehran-sxhvrht3wzt |title = Memoir: The Terminal Man by Sir Alfred Mehran |last = Wavell |first = Stuart |work = The Sunday Times |location = London }}{{subscription required}} == Documentaries and fictionalizations == Nasseri's story provided the inspiration for the 1994 French film ''[[Tombés du ciel]]'', starring [[Jean Rochefort]], internationally released under the title ''Lost in Transit''. The [[short story]] "The Fifteen-Year Layover", written by Michael Paterniti and published in ''[[GQ]]'' and ''The Best American Non-Required Reading'', chronicles Nasseri's life. [[Alexis Kouros]] made a documentary about him, ''Waiting for Godot at De Gaulle'' (2000). [[Glen Luchford]] and Paul Berczeller made the ''Here to Where'' [[mockumentary]] (2001), also featuring Nasseri. Hamid Rahmanian and Melissa Hibbard made a documentary called ''Sir Alfred of Charles De Gaulle Airport'' (2001).{{cite web |url = http://www.fictionvillestudio.com/films/alfred/sir-alfred.html |title = Fictionville Studio promo website |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141106223419/http://fictionvillestudio.com/films/alfred/sir-alfred.html |archive-date = 6 November 2014 }} Nasseri was reportedly the inspiration behind the character Viktor Navorski, from the 2004 Steven Spielberg film ''[[The Terminal]]'';{{cite news |first = Ethan |last = Gilsdorf |url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0621/p11s02-almo.html |title = Behind ''The Terminal'', a true story |work = The Christian Science Monitor |date = 21 June 2004 |access-date = 17 November 2015 }} however, neither publicity materials, nor the [[DVD]] "special features" nor the film's website mentions Nasseri's situation as an inspiration for the film. Despite this, in September 2003, ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted that [[Steven Spielberg]] had bought the rights to his life story as the basis for ''The Terminal''.{{Cite web |last = Rose |first = Matthew |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/21/magazine/magazinespecial/MFMERHANT.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5007&en=360b6f8f63635c6a&ex=1379476800 |title = Waiting For Spielberg |work= [[The New York Times]] |date = 21 September 2003 |accessdate = 12 June 2008 }} ''[[The Guardian]]'' indicates that Spielberg's [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]] production company paid US$250,000 to Nasseri for rights to his story and report that, as of 2004, he carried a poster advertising Spielberg's film draping his [[suitcase]] next to his bench. Nasseri was reportedly excited about ''The Terminal'', but it was unlikely that he would ever have had a chance to see it in cinemas. Nasseri's story was also the inspiration for the contemporary opera ''[[Flight (opera)|Flight]]'' by British composer [[Jonathan Dove]], which won the Helpmann Award at the [[Adelaide Festival Theatre]] in March 2006.{{cite news |url = http://www.playbillarts.com/news/article/4995.html |first1 = Vivien |last1 = Schweitzer |first2 = Matthew |last2 = Westphal |last-author-amp = yes |title = Australia's Helpmann Awards Name Winners |work = Playbill Arts |date = 2 August 2006 }} ==See also== *[[Stateless person]] *[[List of people who have lived at airports]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017091441/http://www.lexpress.fr/info/societe/dossier/immigration/dossier.asp?ida=428703 |date=17 October 2007 |title=Le naufragé du terminal 1 }}, 26 July 2004, {{fr}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nasseri, Merhan Karimi}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Stateless people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Bradford]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Iranian refugees]] [[Category:Iranian people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:People from Masjed Soleyman]]

{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Noel Hinners | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = <!--(filename only, i.e. without "File:" prefix)--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date |1935|12|25}} | birth_place = Brooklyn | death_date = {{death date and age |2014|09|05 |1935|12|25}} | death_place = Littleton, Colorado | death_cause = Basal-cell carcinoma | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = American | fields = Geology and soil chemistry | workplaces = NASA | patrons = | education = Rutgers University | alma_mater = California Institute of Technology | thesis_title = <!--(or | thesis1_title = and | thesis2_title = )--> | thesis_url = <!--(or | thesis1_url = and | thesis2_url = )--> | thesis_year = <!--(or | thesis1_year = and | thesis2_year = )--> | doctoral_advisor = <!--(or | doctoral_advisors = )--> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!--{{URL|www.example.com}}--> | footnotes = }}
'''Noel William Hinners''' (December 25, 1935 – September 5, 2014) was an [[United States|American]] [[geologist]] and [[soil]] [[chemist]] who is primarily remembered for his work with [[NASA]] where he worked in a variety of scientific and administrative roles from 1963-1989, including two years as [[NASA Chief Scientist]]. In 1977 he was awarded the [[NASA Distinguished Service Medal]].
At NASA Hinners helped plan and execute the [[Apollo program]] and was also responsible for the successful launches of numerous scientific probes into space; achieving such notable objectives as the first retrieval of moon rocks, mapping the surface of Mars, and capturing the first photographic images of the birthplace of stars among other achievements. His later work at [[Lockheed Martin]] as vice president of Flight Systems from 1989-2002 remained closely linked with [[NASA]].<ref name="obit"/>
==Life and career== Born in Brooklyn and raised in [[Chatham, New Jersey]], Hinners was one of eight children born to William and Hazel Hinners. His father was an insurance agent, and his mother a homemaker. He earned degrees from [[Rutgers University]] (Bachelor of Agricultural Science, 1958), [[California Institute of Technology]] (master's in Geology), and [[Princeton University]] (Ph.D in Geochemistry, 1963).<ref name="obit"/>
After graduating from Princeton, Hinners worked for [[Bellcomm]], a subsidiary of AT&T that worked closely with [[NASA]]. With Bellcomm he spent the next nine years working on the science of the [[Apollo program]], including making many of the site selections for the Apollo missions. From 1972 to 1974 he served as NASA's director of Lunar Programs and from 1974 to 1979 he was NASA's associate administrator for Space Science.<ref name="obit"/>
In 1979, Hinners left NASA to become the director of the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian's]] [[National Air and Space Museum]]. He left that post in 1982 to become director of the [[NASA Goddard Space Flight Center]] where he remained for almost 6 years. From 1987 to 1989 he served as [[NASA Chief Scientist]] and associate deputy administrator of NASA. He then became vice president of Flight System at [[Lockheed Martin]] where he remained until his retirement in 2002. His work at Lockheed Martin was still closely tied to NASA, including responsibilities for NASA's [[Mars Global Surveyor]], [[Mars Surveyor Program]], [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]], Stardust and Genesis Discovery missions, Space (Nuclear) Power Systems and Mission Operations for NASA/LM planetary missions.<ref name="obit"/>
Hinners died of [[basal-cell carcinoma]]<ref>[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]], ''Obituary'', 15 September 2014, p. 10</ref> at the age of 78 in [[Littleton, Colorado]].<ref name="obit">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/12/us/noel-w-hinners-voice-for-scientific-research-at-nasa-dies-at-78.html?ref=obituaries|title=Noel W. Hinners, Voice for Scientific Research at NASA, Dies at 78|author=Paul Vitello |author-link=Paul Vitello|date=September 11, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11320392 Noel Hinners, former NASA scientist, dies at 78]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hinners, Noel}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Colorado]] [[Category:Deaths from brain tumor]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Rutgers University alumni]]
