{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Orphan|date=December 2012}}
'''Peter Hargitay''' (born 1951) is a [[public relations]] executive and a partner of the European Consultancy Network.<ref name=SMHOct09>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/sport/football/meet-ffas-man-of-mystery/2009/10/17/1255624771126.html|author=Matthew Hall|title=Meet FFA's man of mystery|newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=18 October 2009}}</ref>
In his early career as a public relations professional Hargitay represented [[Union Carbide]] in the aftermath of the [[Bhopal disaster]]<ref name= "Foul!">{{cite book |last=Jennings |first=Andrew|title=Foul! The secret world of FIFA: Bribes, Vote rigging and ticket scandals|publisher=[[Harper Collins]]|year=2006|isbn=978-0-00-720869-2}}</ref> and commodities trader and fugitive [[Marc Rich]].<ref name= "Foul!"/>
In 1980 Hargitay founded the Consulting Group Europe<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Hargitay|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1562738/|work=IMBD|publisher=IMBD.com}}</ref> which specialized in cases involving high-profile companies and individuals who needed help ensuring their reputations. In 1990 Hargitay produced the production of ''King''; a musical based on the life of [[Martin Luther King]].<ref name="CassidyTimes">{{cite news|last1=Cassidy|first1=Suzanne|last2=Times|first2=Special to the New York|title=After Struggle, Musical on Dr. King Is Opening|work=The New York Times|page=11|date=23 April 1990|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/theater/after-struggle-musical-on-dr-king-is-opening.html}}</ref> After Hargitay sold Consulting Group Europe and spent 10 years in Jamaica to focus on his family and producing documentaries, Peter Hargitay re-entered the consulting field in 2002 when he formed ECN Ltd, which was involved in managing numerous high profile corporates and industrial crises.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Hargitay|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/s/#!search/profile/person?personId=386760405&targetid=profile|work=ZoomInfo|publisher=zoominfo.com}}</ref>
Hargitay was one of the executive producers on the 2010 "[[Fire in Babylon]]"<ref>{{cite web|title=Fire in Babylon|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1727790/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|work=IMDB|publisher=imdb.com}}</ref> film, as well as 2005 film ''[[Goal! (film)|Goal!]]'' and the final part of the [[Goal! (trilogy)|''Goal!'' trilogy]], ''[[Goal III: Taking on the World]]''.<ref name='NYTGoal'>{{cite web| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/326392/Goal-The-Dream-Begins/credits|title=Goal! The Dream Begins|publisher=[[New York Times]]| accessdate=8 December 2012}}</ref><ref name='NYTGoal3'>{{cite web| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/446865/Goal-3/details|title=Goal! 3|publisher=[[New York Times]]| accessdate=8 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Goal! The Dream Begins|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0380389/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|work=IMDB|publisher=IMDB.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Official Film of the 2006 FIFA World Cup|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0883377/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|work=IMDB|publisher=imdb.com}}</ref>
Hargitay advised both Chelsea and [[FIFA]] in their dispute at the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] during the [[2009 English football tapping up controversy]].<ref name=MetFeb10>{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2010/02/05/chelsea-look-forward-after-ban-lifted-79641/|title=Chelsea look forward after ban lifted|newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=5 February 2010}}</ref>
In the 2000s Hargitay was a special adviser to [[Sepp Blatter]], the President of the world governing body of football, [[FIFA]]. Hargitay left his job with FIFA to work on [[England 2018 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid for the 2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name=SMHOct09/> After all outside consultants were invited to reapply for the England bid work in a tender process, European Consultancy Network declined and left the bid.<ref name=SMHOct09/> Hargitay's European Consultancy Network were employed by the [[Football Federation Australia|Football Federation of Australia]] to provide strategy and networking advice for [[Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|Australia's bid for the 2022 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name=SMHOct09/> Australia's bid was ultimately unsuccessful, receiving only a single vote in the first round of voting.<ref name=SMHOct09/>
Peter Hargitay has also served as a lecturer at the Universities of Neuchatel, Milan and Leicester and at Bocconi and De Montfort Universities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Hargitay Report|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/212448632/Peter-Hargitay-Report|work=scribd}}</ref> Since 2003, Hargitay has also been lecturing at the Centre for International Sports Studies (CIES) for the Master's Degree Program in Switzerland, Italy and UK.<ref>{{cite web|title=CIES|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/footballdevelopment/education/01/47/84/57/executivesummariesfinal.pdf|work=FIFA|publisher=fifa.com}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.theage.com.au/world-cup-2010/world-cup-news/the-man-behind-our-2022-bid-is-not-exactly-shy-in-coming-forward-20100625-z9pa.html 2010 profile of Hargitay's work for Australia's World Cup bid] *[http://www.theage.com.au/sport/soccer/i-wasnt-paid-4-million--world-cup-lobbyist-20101215-18xit.html The Age] *[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-566898/FA-pay-dropping-Hargitay.html Daily Mail]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hargitay, Peter}} [[Category:Public relations people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1951 births]]

'''Pierre Fakhoury''' (born in Dabou, Côte d'Ivoire) is a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]]/[[Côte d'Ivoire|Ivorian]] architect. Fakhoury graduated at the School of Architecture at [[Tournai]], [[Belgium]].
His notable work includes the [[Basilica of Our Lady of Peace of Yamoussoukro|Basilica of Our Lady of Peace]] in [[Yamoussoukro]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]]. Since 1983, Fakhoury has been involved in the relocation of the capital of Côte d'Ivoire from [[Abidjan]] to [[Yamoussoukro]].
== References == *[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/jeune_afrique/article_jeune_afrique.asp?art_cle=LIN11056pierryruohk0 Pierre Fakhoury] in ''[[Jeune Afrique]]''.
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fakhoury, Pierre}} [[Category:Architects]] [[Category:Ivorian people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Ivorian sculptors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lebanese architects]] [[Category:Lebanese sculptors]]
{{Lebanon-architect-stub}}

{{About|the son of Queen Anne|the brother of King George III|Prince William Henry, Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh|his son|Prince William Frederick, Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh|the grandson of George V|Prince William of Gloucester}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{featured article}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Prince William | title = Duke of Gloucester | image = Prince William of Denmark.jpg | caption =Portrait by Sir [[Godfrey Kneller]], c. 1700 | house = [[House of Oldenburg|Oldenburg]] | father = [[Prince George of Denmark]] | mother = [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1689|7|24}} | birth_place = [[Hampton Court Palace]], London | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1700|7|30|1689|7|24}} | death_place = [[Windsor Castle]], [[Windsor, Berkshire]] | date of burial = 9 August 1700 | place of burial = [[Westminster Abbey]] |}} '''Prince William, Duke of Gloucester''' (24 July 1689 – 30 July 1700{{efn|All dates in this article are in the [[Old Style and New Style dates|Old Style]] [[Julian calendar]] in use in Britain throughout Gloucester's life; however, years are assumed to start on 1 January rather than 25 March, which was the English New Year.}}) was the son of [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Princess Anne]], later Queen of [[Kingdom of England|England]], [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]] and [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scotland]] from 1702, and her husband, [[Prince George of Denmark]]. He was their only child to survive infancy. Styled [[Duke of Gloucester]], he was viewed by contemporaries as a Protestant champion because his birth seemed to cement the Protestant succession established in the "[[Glorious Revolution]]" that had deposed his Catholic grandfather [[James II]] the previous year.
Gloucester's mother was estranged from her brother-in-law and cousin, [[William III of England|William III]], and her sister, [[Mary II]], but supported links between them and her son. He grew close to his uncle William, who created him a [[Knight of the Garter]], and his aunt Mary, who frequently sent him presents. At his nursery in Campden House, [[Kensington]], he befriended his Welsh body-servant, Jenkin Lewis, whose memoir of the Duke is an important source for historians, and operated his own miniature army, called the "Horse Guards", which eventually comprised 90 boys.
Gloucester's precarious health was a constant source of worry to his mother. His death, in 1700 at the age of 11, precipitated a succession crisis as his mother was the only individual remaining in the Protestant line of succession established by the [[Bill of Rights 1689]]. The [[English Parliament]] did not want the throne to revert to a Catholic, and so passed the [[Act of Settlement 1701]], which settled the throne of England on [[Electress Sophia of Hanover]], a cousin of King James II, and her Protestant heirs.
==Birth and health== [[File:Queen Anne and William, Duke of Gloucester by studio of Sir Godfrey Kneller.jpg|thumb|left|[[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Princess Anne]] embraces her only surviving child, the Duke of Gloucester, in a painting by [[Godfrey Kneller|Sir Godfrey Kneller]], c. 1694.|alt=Anne and her son embrace against a Baroque garden background]] In late 1688, in what became known as the "[[Glorious Revolution]]", the [[Roman Catholic]] [[James II of England|King James]] of [[Kingdom of England|England]], [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scotland]] and [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]] was deposed by his [[Protestant]] nephew and son-in-law, Dutch [[stadtholder]] [[William III of Orange]]. William and his wife, James's elder daughter [[Mary II of England|Mary]], were recognised by the [[Parliament of England|English]] and [[Parliament of Scotland|Scottish]] parliaments as king and queen. As they had no children, Mary's younger sister, [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]], was designated their [[heir presumptive]] in England and Scotland.<ref>Gregg, pp. 63–69; Somerset, pp. 98–110</ref> The accession of William and Mary and the succession through Anne were enshrined in the [[Bill of Rights 1689]].<ref>Somerset, p. 109</ref>
Anne was married to [[Prince George of Denmark]], and in their six years of marriage Anne had been pregnant six times, but none of her children had survived. Her seventh pregnancy resulted in the birth of a son at 5 a.m. on 24 July 1689 in [[Hampton Court Palace]]. As it was usual for the births of potential heirs to the throne to be attended by several witnesses, the King and Queen and "most of the persons of quality about the court" were present.<ref>Gregg, p. 72; Somerset, p. 113</ref> Three days later, the newborn baby was baptised William Henry after his uncle King William by [[Henry Compton (bishop)|Henry Compton]], [[Bishop of London]]. The King, who was one of the godparents along with the [[George Savile, 1st Marquess of Halifax#Family|Marchioness of Halifax]]<ref>Chapman, p. 21</ref> and the [[Lord Chamberlain]], [[Charles Sackville, 6th Earl of Dorset|Lord Dorset]],<ref>Gregg, p. 72</ref> declared him [[Duke of Gloucester]],<ref>Chapman, p. 21; Green, p. 54; Gregg, p. 72</ref> although the peerage was never formally created.<ref name=Gibbs>Gibbs and Doubleday, p. 743</ref> Gloucester was second in line to the throne after his mother, and because his birth secured the Protestant succession, he was the hope of the revolution's supporters.<ref name=Chapman46>Chapman, p. 46</ref> The ode ''The Noise of Foreign Wars'', attributed to [[Henry Purcell]], was written in celebration of the birth.<ref>White, Brian (Winter 2007). "Music for a 'brave livlylike boy': the Duke of Gloucester, Purcell and 'The noise of foreign wars'" ''The Musical Times'' '''148''' (1901): 75–83</ref> Other congratulatory odes, such as Purcell's last royal ode ''Who Can From Joy Refrain?'' and [[John Blow]]'s ''The Duke of Gloucester's March'' and ''A Song upon the Duke of Gloucester'', were composed for his birthdays in later years.<ref>Baldwin, Olive; Wilson, Thelma (September 1981). "Who Can from Joy Refraine? Purcell's Birthday Song for the Duke of Gloucester" ''The Musical Times'' '''122''' (1663): 596–599</ref><ref>McGuinness, Rosamund (April 1965). "The Chronology of John Blow's Court Odes" ''Music and Letters'' '''46''' (2): 102–121</ref> Opponents of the revolution, supporters of James known as the [[Jacobitism|Jacobites]], spoke of Gloucester as "a sickly and doomed usurper".<ref name=Chapman46/>
Though described as a "brave livlylike {{sic}} boy",<ref>Letter from [[George Melville, 1st Earl of Melville|Lord Melville]] to the [[William Douglas-Hamilton, Duke of Hamilton|Duke of Hamilton]], 26 July 1689, quoted in Gregg, p. 76 and Waller, p. 296</ref> Gloucester became ill with [[convulsions]] when he was three weeks old, so his mother moved him into Craven House, Kensington, hoping that the air from the surrounding gravel pits would have a beneficial effect on his health.<ref>Waller, p. 296</ref> His convulsions were possibly symptomatic of [[meningitis]], likely contracted at birth and which resulted in [[hydrocephalus]].<ref name="Somerset, p. 116">Somerset, p. 116</ref> As was usual among royalty, Gloucester was placed in the care of a governess, [[Barbara Berkeley, Viscountess Fitzhardinge|Lady Fitzhardinge]],<ref name=Chapman49/> and was suckled by a [[wet nurse]], [[Mrs. Pack]], rather than his mother.{{efn|Mrs Pack was said to be so ugly that she was "fitter to go to a pigsty than to a prince's bed".<ref>Somerset, p. 113</ref> She apparently failed to gain Gloucester's affection; on her death in 1694, he was asked by the Queen if he was sad at the news, to which he replied, "No, madam".<ref name="Somerset 145">Somerset, p. 145</ref>}} As part of his treatment, Gloucester was driven outside every day in a small open carriage, pulled by [[Shetland pony|Shetland ponies]], to maximise his exposure to the air of the gravel pits.<ref>Chapman, p. 31</ref> When the effectiveness of this treatment exceeded their expectations, Princess Anne and her husband acquired a permanent residence in the area, Campden House, a [[Jacobean architecture|Jacobean]] mansion, in 1690.<ref>Chapman, pp. 31–32</ref> It was here that Gloucester befriended Welsh body-servant Jenkin Lewis, whose memoir of his master is an important source for historians.<ref>Gregg, p. 100</ref>
Throughout his life, Gloucester suffered from a recurrent "ague", which was treated with regular doses of [[Jesuit's bark]] (an early form of [[quinine]]) by his physician, [[John Radcliffe (physician)|John Radcliffe]]. Gloucester disliked the treatment intensely, and usually vomited after being given it.<ref>Green, p. 64</ref> Possibly as a result of hydrocephalus,<ref name="Green55">Green, p. 55</ref><ref name="Somerset, p. 116"/> he had an enlarged head, which his surgeons pierced intermittently to draw off fluid.<ref>Chapman, pp. 30–31; Curtis, p. 74</ref> He could not walk properly, and was apt to stumble.<ref name="Green55" /> Nearing the age of five, Gloucester refused to climb stairs without two attendants to hold him, which Lewis blamed on indulgent nurses who over-protected the boy. His father [[Birching|birched]] him until he agreed to walk by himself.<ref>Chapman, pp. 57, 74–75</ref> [[Corporal punishment]] was usual at the time, and such treatment would not have been considered harsh.<ref>Somerset, p. 144</ref>
==Education== [[File:PrinceWilliamDukeOfGloucester.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait by Edmund Lilly of Prince William in the azure mantle of the [[Order of the Garter]], c. 1698.]] Gloucester's [[language acquisition]] was delayed: he did not speak correctly until the age of three,<ref>Gregg, p. 100; Waller, p. 317</ref> and consequently the commencement of his education was postponed by a year.<ref>Chapman, p. 43</ref> The Reverend Samuel Pratt, a [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] graduate, was appointed the Duke's tutor in 1693.<ref name=Chapman49>Chapman, p. 49</ref> Lessons concentrated on geography, mathematics, Latin, and French.<ref name="Somerset 145"/> Pratt was an enemy of Jenkin Lewis, and they frequently disagreed over how Gloucester should be educated.<ref name=Chapman49/> Lewis remained Gloucester's favourite attendant because, unlike Pratt, he was knowledgeable in military matters and could therefore help him with his "Horse Guards",<ref>Chapman, p. 54</ref> a miniature army consisting of local children.<ref>Brown, p. 141; Chapman, pp. 53, 59</ref> Over a couple of years from 1693, the size of the army grew from 22 to over 90 boys.<ref name=Kilburn>{{Cite web|author=Kilburn, Matthew|year=2004|title=William, Prince, duke of Gloucester (1689–1700)|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/29454|work=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=8 October 2011|doi= 10.1093/ref:odnb/29454}} {{Subscription required}}</ref>
Princess Anne had fallen out with her sister and brother-in-law, William and Mary, and reluctantly agreed to the advice of her friend, the [[Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough|Countess of Marlborough]], that Gloucester should visit his aunt and uncle regularly to ensure their continued goodwill towards him.<ref>Gregg, pp. 98–99</ref> In an attempt to heal the rift, Anne invited the King and Queen to see Gloucester drill the "Horse Guards".<ref>Waller, p. 320</ref> After watching the boys' display at [[Kensington Palace]], the King praised them, and made a return visit to Campden House the following day.<ref>Chapman, p. 65</ref> Gloucester grew closer to his aunt and uncle: the Queen bought him presents from his favourite toy shop regularly.<ref>Waller, p. 317</ref> Her death in 1694 led to a superficial reconciliation between Anne and William, which occasioned a move to [[St James's Palace]], London.<ref>Gregg, pp. 105–107</ref> Gloucester having tired of him, Lewis only attended St James's every two months.<ref>Chapman, p. 89</ref>
On his seventh birthday, Gloucester attended a ceremony at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]], to install him as a knight of the [[Order of the Garter]], an honour the King had given him six months before. Gloucester became ill during the celebratory banquet afterwards and left early, but after his recovery went [[deer hunting]] in [[Windsor Great Park]], where he was [[wiktionary:blood#Verb|blooded]] by [[Samuel Masham, 1st Baron Masham|Samuel Masham]], his father's [[Page (occupation)|page]].<ref name=Green74>Green, p. 74</ref> Princess Anne wrote to the Countess of Marlborough, "My boy continues yet very well, and looks better, I think, than ever he did in his life; I mean more healthy, for though I love him very well, I can't brag of his beauty."<ref name=Green74/>
[[File:King William and Prince William.jpg|thumb|left|King William III entrusting Prince William to Bishop Burnet, illustrated in [[John Cassell]]'s ''Illustrated History of England'']] During the trial of [[Sir John Fenwick, 3rd Baronet|Sir John Fenwick]], who was implicated in [[Jacobite assassination plot 1696|a plot to assassinate King William]],<ref>Churchill, vol. I, p. 401</ref> Gloucester signed a letter to the King promising his loyalty. "I, your Majesty's most dutiful subject," the letter read, "had rather lose my life in your Majesty's cause than in any man's else, and I hope it will not be long ere you conquer France."<ref name=Churchill446>Churchill, vol. I, p. 446</ref> Added to the letter was a declaration by the boys in Gloucester's army: "We, your Majesty's subjects, will stand by you while we have a drop of blood."<ref name=Churchill446/>
In 1697, Parliament granted King William £50,000 to establish a household for the Duke of Gloucester, though the King only permitted the release of £15,000, keeping the difference for himself.<ref name=Gregg114>Gregg, p. 114</ref> The establishment of Gloucester's own household in early 1698 revived the feud between Anne and William.<ref>Chapman, p. 131</ref> William was determined to limit Anne's involvement in the household, and therefore appointed, against her wishes, the [[low church]] [[Gilbert Burnet]], [[Bishop of Salisbury]], as Gloucester's [[preceptor]].<ref>Green, p. 78; Gregg, p. 115</ref> Anne was [[high church]],<ref>Somerset, p. 157</ref> and Burnet, knowing she was unhappy, attempted to decline the appointment, but the King insisted he accept it.<ref>Chapman, p. 133; Green, p. 78; Gregg, p. 115</ref> Anne's anger was only placated by an assurance from King William that she could choose all the lower servants of the household.<ref name=Gregg115>Gregg, p. 115</ref> The [[John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough|Earl of Marlborough]], a friend of Anne's, was appointed Gloucester's governor, after the [[Charles Talbot, 1st Duke of Shrewsbury|Duke of Shrewsbury]] declined the office on the grounds of ill health.<ref name=Gregg114/> Shortly before the King sailed for the Netherlands, he received Anne's choices from Marlborough but he refused to confirm them.<ref name=Gregg115/> His favourite, the [[Arnold van Keppel, 1st Earl of Albemarle|Earl of Albemarle]], eventually convinced him to agree to Anne's appointments, and the King's acceptance was sent from the Netherlands in September 1698.<ref>Gregg, p. 116</ref> The Marlboroughs' twelve-year-old son, [[John Churchill, Marquess of Blandford|Lord Churchill]], was appointed Gloucester's [[Master of the Horse]], and became a friend and playmate.<ref>Churchill, vol. I, p. 433</ref> [[Abigail Masham, Baroness Masham|Abigail Hill]], a kinswoman of the Countess of Marlborough, was appointed his laundress, and Abigail's brother, [[John Hill (courtier)|Jack Hill]], was made one of Gloucester's [[Gentleman of the Bedchamber|gentlemen of the bedchamber]].<ref>Churchill, vol. I, pp. 433–434</ref>
[[File:William, Duke of Gloucester by Sir Godfrey Kneller, Bt.jpg|thumb|Portrait by [[Godfrey Kneller|Sir Godfrey Kneller]], c. 1698]] Burnet lectured Gloucester for hours at a time on subjects such as the feudal constitutions of Europe and law before the time of Christianity.<ref name=Chapman137>Chapman, p. 137</ref> Burnet also encouraged Gloucester to memorise facts and dates by heart.<ref name=Chapman137/> Government ministers inspected Gloucester's academic progress every four months, finding themselves "amazed" by his "wonderful memory and good judgement".<ref name=Chapman137/> His childhood troop was disbanded, and King William made him the honorary commander of a real regiment of Dutch footguards.<ref>Chapman, p. 134</ref> In 1699, he attended the [[List of trials of peers in the House of Lords|trials in the House of Lords]] of [[Charles Mohun, 4th Baron Mohun|Lord Mohun]] and [[Edward Rich, 6th Earl of Warwick|Lord Warwick]], who were accused of murder.<ref name=Kilburn/> Mohun was acquitted; Warwick was found guilty of manslaughter but escaped punishment by pleading [[privilege of peerage]].<ref>Lovell, C. R. (October 1949). "The Trial of Peers in Great Britain" ''The American Historical Review'' '''55''': 69–81</ref>
==Death== As he neared his eleventh birthday, Gloucester was assigned the rooms in Kensington Palace that had been used by his aunt, Queen Mary, who died in 1694.<ref name=Kilburn/> At his birthday party at Windsor, on 24 July 1700, he complained of a sudden fatigue, but was initially thought to have overheated himself while dancing.<ref name=Waller352>Waller, p. 352</ref> By nightfall, he was suffering from a sore throat and chills, followed by a severe headache and a high fever the next day.<ref name=Waller352/><ref name=Somerset164>Somerset, p. 164</ref> A physician, Hannes, did not arrive until 27 July. Gloucester was immediately [[Bloodletting|bled]], but his condition continued to deteriorate. Over the next day, he developed a rash and suffered a bout of diarrhoea. A second physician, Gibbons, arrived early on 28 July, followed by Radcliffe that evening.<ref name=Somerset164/>
The physicians could not agree on a diagnosis.<ref name=Waller352/> Radcliffe thought he had [[scarlet fever]], while others thought it was [[smallpox]].<ref name="Green">Green, p. 79</ref> They administered "cordial powders and cordial juleps".<ref name=Somerset164/> Gloucester was bled, to which Radcliffe strongly objected. He told his colleagues, "you have destroyed him and you may finish him".<ref name="Green" /> He prescribed blistering, which was no more effective.<ref>Chapman, p. 138</ref> In great pain, Gloucester passed the evening of 28 July "in great sighings and dejections of spirits ... towards morning, he complained very much of his blisters."<ref name=Somerset164/> Anne, who had spent an entire day and night by her son's bedside, now became so distressed that she fainted.<ref name=Somerset164/> However, by midday on 29 July, Gloucester was breathing more easily and his headache had diminished, leading to hopes that he would recover. The improvement was fleeting, and that evening, he was "taken with a convulsing sort of breathing, a defect in swallowing and a total deprivation of all sense".<ref name=Somerset164/> Prince William died close to 1 a.m. on 30 July 1700, with his parents beside him. In the end, the physicians decided the cause of death was "a malignant fever".<ref name=Somerset164/> An autopsy revealed severe swelling of the [[lymph nodes]] in the neck and an abnormal amount of fluid in the [[Ventricular system|ventricles]] of his brain:<ref>Gregg, p. 120</ref> "four and a half ounces of a limpid humour were taken out."<ref name=Somerset164/> A modern diagnosis is that Gloucester died of acute [[Streptococcal pharyngitis|bacterial pharyngitis]], with associated [[pneumonia]]. Had he lived, though, it is almost certain the prince would have succumbed to complications of his hydrocephalus.<ref name=Somerset164/>
King William, who was in the Netherlands, wrote to Marlborough, "It is so great a loss to me as well as to all England, that it pierces my heart."<ref>Chapman, p. 142; Churchill, vol. I, p. 447</ref> Anne was prostrate with grief, taking to her chamber.<ref name="Somerset 163">Somerset, p. 163</ref> In the evenings, she was carried into the garden "to divert her melancholy thoughts".<ref name=Somerset164/> Gloucester's body was moved from Windsor to Westminster on the night of 1 August, and he lay in state in the [[Palace of Westminster]] before being entombed in the Royal Vault of the [[Henry VII Chapel]] in [[Westminster Abbey]] on 9 August.<ref>Chapman, pp. 143–144; Green, p. 80; Gregg, p. 120</ref> As was usual for royalty in mourning, his parents did not attend the funeral service, instead remaining in seclusion at Windsor.<ref name="Somerset 163"/>
In an allusion to Prince William's death, [[Tories (British political party)|Tory]] politician [[William Shippen (MP)|William Shippen]] wrote: :So by the course of the revolving spheres, :Whene'er a new-discovered star appears, :Astronomers, with pleasure and amaze, :Upon the infant luminary gaze. :They find their heaven's enlarged, and wait from thence :Some blest, some more than common influence, :But suddenly, alas! The fleeting light, :Retiring, leaves their hopes involv'd in endless night.<ref>Jacob, pp. 306–307</ref>
Gloucester's death destabilised the succession, as his mother was the only person remaining in the Protestant line to the throne established by the [[Bill of Rights 1689]].<ref name=Waller352/> Although Anne had ten other pregnancies after the birth of Gloucester, none of them resulted in a child who survived more than briefly after birth.<ref>Green, p. 335</ref> The English parliament did not want the throne to revert to a Catholic,<ref>Starkey, p. 216</ref> so it passed the [[Act of Settlement 1701]], which settled the throne of England on a cousin of King James, [[Sophia of Hanover|Sophia, Electress of Hanover]], and her Protestant heirs.<ref>Starkey, pp. 215–216</ref> Anne succeeded King William in 1702, and reigned until her death on 1 August 1714. Sophia predeceased her by a few weeks, and so Sophia's son [[George I of Great Britain|George]] ascended the throne as the first British monarch of the [[House of Hanover]].<ref>Gregg, pp. 384, 394–397</ref>
==Titles, styles, honours and arms== [[File:Coat of Arms of William of Denmark, Duke of Gloucester.svg|thumb|200px|The Duke of Gloucester's arms]] William was styled as: His Royal Highness Prince William, Duke of Gloucester.<ref>Chapman, p. 90</ref>
===Honours=== *'''KG''': [[Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]], 6 January 1696<ref name=Gibbs/>
===Arms=== Gloucester bore the [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom|royal arms]], [[Cadency|differenced]] by an [[inescutcheon]] of the [[Coat of arms of Denmark|Danish coat of arms]] and a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points [[Argent]], the centre point bearing a cross [[Gules]].<ref>Ashmole, p. 539</ref> {{clear}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Rachel Cheung | image = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Cheung Wai-Ching | native_name = 張緯晴 | native_name_lang = zho | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|9|27}} | birth_place = [[Hong Kong]] | origin = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) --> | death_place = | genre = [[Classical music|Classical]] | occupation = [[Pianist]] | instrument = [[Piano]] | years_active = 2004–present | label = The Alpha Omega Sound, VAI Music | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|rachelcheung.com}} }}
{{Infobox Chinese |t=張緯晴 |s=张纬晴 |p=Zhāng Wěi Qíng |w=Chang<sup>1</sup> Wei<sup>3</sup> Ch'ing<sup>2</sup> |poj= |j=Zoeng<sup>1</sup> Wai<sup>5</sup> Ceng<sup>4</sup> }}
'''Rachel Wai-Ching Cheung''' ({{zh|t=張緯晴|j=Zoeng<sup>1</sup> Wai<sup>5</sup> Ceng<sup>4</sup>}}; born September 27, 1991) is a classical [[pianist]] from [[Kowloon]], [[Hong Kong]].<ref name="The Fryderyk Chopin Institute - Wai-Ching Rachel Cheung">{{cite web|title=Persons Related to Chopin - Wai-Ching Rachel Cheung|url=http://en.chopin.nifc.pl/chopin/persons/detail/bio/yes/page/4/id/7311|website=The Fryderyk Chopin Institute|publisher=Narodowy Instytut Fryderyka Chopina|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> She has won numerous prizes and awards in Hong Kong and overseas, and performs regularly in Asia, Europe, and North America.<ref name="Guandong">{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsgd.com/culture/art/200407200013.htm|title=A little maestro amazes SZ music lovers|accessdate=2007-04-24|publisher=News Guandong|year=2004}}</ref><ref name="Liang">{{Cite web|url=http://www.inkpot.com/concert/rachelcheung.html|title=Rachel Cheung Piano Recital 14/12/06 - The Love of Music Festival|accessdate=2007-08-03|publisher=The Flying Inkpot|year=2006|author=Chang Tou Liang|work=Concert Review }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Cheung comes from a musical family. Her father, a piano teacher, gave her first [[piano]] lessons at age four.<ref name="SCMP Keys to my success">{{cite news|last1=Olluver|first1=Sam|title=Keys to my success|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/1006178/keys-my-success|accessdate=6 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post|issue=International Edition|publisher=South China Morning Post Publishers Limited|date=July 8, 2012}}</ref> At age ten, she was admitted to [[The Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts]] (HKAPA) as a junior student studying under Professor [[Eleanor Wong (musician)|Eleanor Wong]], Artist-in-Residence and Senior Lecturer in Keyboard.<ref name="Guandong" /> She also attended secondary school at the [[Maryknoll Convent School]].<ref name="SCMP Keys to my success" /> For college, she continued studies at HKAPA with Professor Wong and obtained her [[Bachelor of Music]] degree in Piano Performance with First Class Honours in June 2011 on a full scholarship from the Robert H.N. Ho Family Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|title=People > Alumni > Graduates > School of Music > 2011|url=http://www.hkapa.edu/graduate/music/2011/|website=The Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref>
In September 2011, Cheung began studies overseas with Professor [[Peter Frankl]] at the [[Yale School of Music]] in the USA on full scholarships from Yale and the [[Hong Kong Jockey Club]] Music and Dance Fund Scholarship.<ref name="HKAPA July 2012 News">{{cite news|title=No place like the Academy - Music graduate Rachel Cheung Wai-ching|url=https://www.hkapa.edu/f/page/5898/07news12.pdf|accessdate=6 September 2015|work=The Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts News|issue=07 2012|date=July 2012}}</ref> She was awarded the Elizabeth Parisot Prize with Larry Weng for outstanding pianists at the Yale School of Music during school year 2011–2012.<ref name="Yale School of Music 2012 Prize Winners">{{cite web|title=Congratulations to the 2012 Prize Winners|url=http://music.yale.edu/2012/04/30/congratulations-to-the-2012-prize-winners/|website=Yale School of Music|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> On May 20, 2013 Cheung was conferred the [[Master of Music]] degree in piano at Yale School of Music's 120th Commencement.<ref name="Yale School of Music 2013 Commencement">{{cite journal|title=One Hundred Twentieth Commencement|journal=The School of Music Yale University|date=May 20, 2013|volume=120|page=4|url=http://issuu.com/yalemusic/docs/2013commencement|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=School of Music 2013–2014|journal=Bulletin of Yale University|date=July 25, 2013|volume=Series 109|issue= 8|page=139|url=http://www.yale.edu/printer/bulletin/archivepdffiles/Music/Music_2013-2014.pdf|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
==Awards==
===Junior competitions=== In 2001 Cheung won First Prize in the Hong Kong regional competition of the [[Steinway & Sons|Steinway and Sons]] International Youth Piano Competition. At her first competition in Europe, she claimed First Prize at the 2002 [[Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod]] for Western Instrumental Group under 15 in [[Wales]]. In May 2003, Cheung won First Prize in the Junior Group (under age 15) at the “5th Biennial [[International Competition for Young Pianists in Memory of Vladimir Horowitz]]” in the [[Ukraine]]. Besides winning the Gold Medal, she was awarded three special prizes from the jury: Most Outstanding Concerto Performance, Best Performance of Romantic Period Pieces, and Youngest Participant of the Competition. Also in 2003, Cheung was awarded First Prize in the Piano Solo division and First Prize in the Piano Concerto under Age 18 division at the 55th Hong Kong School Music Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=Music Achievements 2002–2003|url=http://www.mcsps.edu.hk/achievement02-03/Music.htm|website=Maryknoll Convent School (Primary Section)|publisher=Maryknoll Convent School|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> In June 2004, she won First Prize and a Peer Jury Prize for the most popular finalist at the 2004 [[Gina Bachauer International Piano Competition|Gina Bachauer International Junior Piano Competition]] in Salt Lake City, Utah.
===Senior competitions=== In 2008, Cheung won second prize at the [[Alessandro Casagrande]] International Piano Competition in [[Terni]], Italy.<ref name="Guandong"/> In September 2009 she won fifth prize at the [[Leeds International Pianoforte Competition]], the best result a Hong Kong pianist has achieved in this prestigious competition. She was also a semi-finalist at the [[XVI International Chopin Piano Competition]] in Warsaw in October 2010. In November 2012, Cheung was awarded the George Leibenson Special Prize at the 67th [[Geneva International Music Competition]] in Piano.<ref>{{cite web|title=Archives - 2012 - piano|url=http://www.concoursgeneve.ch/sections/archives?a=collapse46|website=Geneva International Music Competition|publisher=Geneva International Music Competition|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
In 2017, Cheung was a finalist and won the Audience Award in the [[Fifteenth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition]] in Fort Worth, Texas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cliburn.org/2017-cliburn-competition/2017-competition-prizes/|title=2017 Competition Prizes – The Cliburn|website=www.cliburn.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref> ''The Dallas Morning News'' called her “a poet, but also a dramatist,” displaying “the most sophisticated and compelling music-making.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/arts/classical-music/2017/06/04/two-different-piano-recitals-sunday-afternoon-cliburn|title=Two very different piano recitals Sunday afternoon at the Cliburn|date=2017-06-04|work=Dallas News|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en}}</ref>
==Career==
===2005=== On April 14, 2005, 13-year-old Cheung performed an extraordinary program to thunderous applause, cheers, and whistles at the 2005 Miami International Piano Festival at the [[Broward Center for the Performing Arts]] in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. She performed Bach's [[Chromatic Fantasia and Fugue|Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue in D minor]], Haydn's [[Piano Sonata Hob. XVI/52|Piano Sonata in E-flat major]], Liszt's "[[Three Concert Études#Étude No. 2, La leggierezza|Étude in F minor, La leggierezza]]," "[[Au bord d'une source]] (S.156, No. 2b)," and "[[Grandes études de Paganini|Étude No. 5 in E major, La chasse]],' Chopin's "[[Miscellaneous compositions (Chopin)|Variations brilliantes in B-flat major]]," Faure's "[[Piano music of Gabriel Fauré|Nocturne No. 1 in E-flat minor," "Barcarolle No. 4 in A-flat major," and "Impromptu No. 2 in F minor]]," and Prokofiev's "[[List of compositions by Sergei Prokofiev#Other piano works|Suggestion diabolique, Op. 4, No. 4]]" and "[[Piano Sonata No. 3 (Prokofiev)|Piano Sonata No. 3 in A minor, Op. 28]]." When it was over, the audience presented Cheung with seven bouquets and a stuffed lamb.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goldberg Longstreth|first1=Peg|title=Review: 13-year-old pianist well-worth the drive to other coast|url=http://www.miamipianofest.com/press/pr2005_cheung_naplesdailynews.html|website=Miami International Piano Festival|publisher=Miami International Piano Festival|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
===2006=== On December 14, 2006 Cheung played a solo recital at [[Hong Kong City Hall]] Concert Hall at The Joy of Music Festival organized by the Chopin Society of Hong Kong. Her programme included Mozart's [[Fantasia No. 2 (Mozart)|Fantasy No. 2 in C minor, K. 396/385f]] and [[Piano Sonata No. 18 (Mozart)|Piano Sonata No. 18 in D major, K. 576]]; Liszt's [[Harmonies poétiques et religieuses|Bénédiction de Dieu dans la solitude]] and [[Two Concert Études (Liszt)|Two Concert Studies]]; Schubert's [[Impromptus (Schubert)#Drei Klavierstücke, D. 946|Three Piano Pieces, D. 946]]; Chopin's [[Mazurkas, Op. 24 (Chopin)|Four Mazurkas, Op. 24]] and [[Ballades (Chopin)#Ballade No. 4|Ballade in F minor, Op. 52, No. 4]] and Poulenc's ''Trois pièces'', [[FP (Poulenc)#48|FP 48]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kwong|first1=Kevin|title=The Joy of Music|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/575310/joy-music|accessdate=8 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post (International Edition)|publisher=South China Morning Post Publishers Limited|date=December 14, 2006}}</ref>
===2007=== On July 15, 2007, 15-year-old Cheung opened the 2007 [[Golandsky Institute]] International Piano Festival by performing works by Chopin, Copland, Mozart, and Schumann at Taplin Auditorium in Fine Hall at [[Princeton University]], New Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|title=2007 International Piano Festival|url=http://www.golandskyinstitute.org/symposium/archive/2007-summer-symposium#internationalpianofestival|website=The Golandsky Institute|publisher=The Golandsky Institute|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=In the Region - New Jersey Calendar of Events|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/08/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/08listingsnj.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=7 September 2015|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=July 8, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Finane|first1=Ben|title=Realizing Bach's ultimate power|url=http://blog.nj.com/ledgerentertainment/2007/07/realizing_bachs_ultimate_power.html|website=NJ.com|publisher=New Jersey On-Line LLC|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
===2012=== On February 25, 2012 Cheung performed [[Six Pieces for Piano, Op. 118 (Brahms)|Johannes Brahms’s Six Pieces, Op. 118]] as part of The Kennedy Center's Conservatory Project featuring Yale School of Music students on The Millennium Stage at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]] in Washington, DC.<ref>{{cite web|title=YSM students participate in the Kennedy Center’s Conservatory Project 2012|url=http://music.yale.edu/2012/02/14/ysm-students-participate-in-the-kennedy-centers-conservatory-project-2012/|website=Yale School of Music|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Yale School of Music 2/25/12 video|url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/explorer/videos/?id=M4949&type=A|website=The Kennedy Center|publisher=The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> On December 3, 2012 she performed [[Piano Sonata No. 15 (Mozart)|W.A. Mozart: Sonata No. 15 in F major, K. 533/494]] in a piano master class with [[Robert D. Levin]] at Parker Recital Hall in Leigh Hall, Yale University.<ref>{{cite web|title=Concerts & master classes with clarinetist Charles Neidich, pianist Robert Levin|url=http://music.yale.edu/2012/11/29/concerts-master-classes-with-clarinetist-charles-neidich-pianist-robert-levin/|website=Yale School of Music|publisher=Yale|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
===2013=== On September 26, 2013 Cheung performed a duo recital "A Musical Dialogue" with [[bassoonist]] Chan Ting Yuen in the [[Citibank Plaza]] lobby, Central, Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite web|title=Community Events - 26 September 2013 - A Musical Dialogue by Rachel Cheung & Chan Ting Yuen|url=http://www.citibankplaza.com/eng/community_detail.jsp?pgcode=5ceac0af-5fe8-479b-8b1d-ff7655efeafe|website=Citibank Plaza|publisher=Champion REIT|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kang|first1=Sunny|title=Rachel Cheung, Piano Recital, Yale School of Music Class of 2013|url=http://www.yaleclubhk.org/event_details.aspx?id=164|website=Yale Club of Hong Kong|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
===2014=== On January 24, 2014 Cheung played a piano duet recital with Dr. Helen Cha at the Y.C. Cheng Lecture Theatre of the [[Hong Kong Baptist University]] in Kowloon.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Helen Cha and Rachel Cheung - Piano Duet Recital|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/668465693204043/|website=Facebook|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
===2015=== On October 4, 2015 Cheung made her debut at the Stars of Steinway Recital Series at Dunkley Music in [[Meridian, Idaho]]. Her season-opening concert was sponsored by Dunkley Music and Pianoconcert Idaho. She played Oiseaux tristes, Une barque sur l'ocean, and Alborada del gracioso from Ravel's [[Miroirs]], Brahms' [[Four Pieces for Piano, Op. 119 (Brahms)|Four Piano Pieces, Op. 119]], and Prokofiev's [[Piano Sonata No. 6 (Prokofiev)|Piano Sonata No. 6 in A major, Op. 82]]. Receiving multiple standing ovations and applause, she played two encores: Chopin's [[Preludes (Chopin)|Prelude Op. 28, No. 6]] and Liszt's [[La Campanella]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stars of Steinway recital series opens|url=http://www.idahostatesman.com/2015/10/02/4014455/stars-of-steinway-recital-series.html|accessdate=13 October 2015|work=Idaho Statesman|publisher=Idaho Statesman|date=October 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=EVENTS - Stars of Steinway|url=http://events.ktvb.com/Stars_of_Steinway/322630075.html|accessdate=13 October 2015|work=7 KTVB.COM|publisher=KTVB|date=October 2015}}</ref>
==Discography== {|class="wikitable" ! ! title ! works ! label ! recording date ! recording location ! release date ! catalog number ! length ! format |- | 1. | Rachel Cheung: Keyboard Prodigy Live in Recital<ref name="VAI Rachel Cheung: Keyboard Prodigy">{{cite web|title=Rachel Cheung: Keyboard Prodigy|url=https://www.vaimusic.com/VIDEO/DVD_4427_Cheung.htm|website=Video Artists International and VAI Audio|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> | Bach, Haydn, Liszt, Chopin, Fauré, Prokofiev, Copland, Field | Video Artists International (VAI) | April 14, 2005 | Amaturo Theater, [[Broward Center for the Performing Arts]], 2005 [[Miami]] International Piano Festival, [[Fort Lauderdale]], Florida, USA (live) | May 29, 2007 | VAI DVD 4427 | 76:00 | [[DVD]] |- | 2. | Rachel Cheung, Piano: Works by Mozart, Liszt, Schubert, Chopin and Poulenc<ref name="The Alpha Omega Sound">{{cite web|title=The Alpha Omega Sound|url=http://www.chopinsocietyhk.org/alpha_omega/index.htm|website=The Chopin Society of Hong Kong Limited|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> | Mozart, Schubert, Chopin, Liszt, Poulenc | The Alpha Omega Sound (The Chopin Society of Hong Kong Limited) | 2007 | Hong Kong (studio), mastered at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in London | 2009 | AOS-07-1003-1-1000-RACHEL CHEUNG | 75:17 | [[CD]] |- |}

{{BLP sources|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox politician | honorific-prefix = | name = Richard Tsoi Yiu-cheong | native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|zh|蔡耀昌}}}} | image = Richard Tsoi in 2010 Hong Kong 1 July marches.JPG | imagesize = 200px | caption = Richard Tsoi in 2010 Hong Kong [[July 1 marches]] | office = Member of the [[Sha Tin District Council]] | term_start = 2004 | term_end = 2007 | predecessor = [[Porinda Liu]] | successor = [[Scarlett Pong]] | constituency = [[Fo Tan]] | office1=Secretary-General of the [[Hong Kong Federation of Students]] | term_start1=1990 | term_end1=1991 | predecessor1 = [[Andrew To]] | successor1 = [[Adeline Wong]] | ancestry = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|09|11}} | birth_place = [[Hong Kong]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Right of abode issue, Hong Kong#Citizenship and residence in Hong Kong|Hong Kong Chinese]] | spouse = Chine Chan | party = [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]] (2008–)
[[The Frontier (Hong Kong)|Frontier]] (?—2008) | relations = | children = | residence = [[Hong Kong]] | alma_mater = [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]], [[University of Hong Kong]], [[Tsinghua University]] and [[People's University of China]].[https://www.facebook.com/yctsoi/info Richard Tsoi's Facebook] | occupation = [[Politician]] | profession = | website = }} {{Infobox Chinese |order= |showflag= |c=蔡耀昌 |p=Cài Yàochāng |j=Coi3 Jiu6 coeng1 |y=Choi Yiuh chēung }} '''Richard Tsoi''' (born 11 September 1967[http://www.dphkweb.org/11dc/dinfo.php?id=129 蔡耀昌TSOI Yiu Cheong Richard - 民主黨2011年區議會選舉網站][https://www.facebook.com/yctsoi/info Richard Tsoi's Facebook]) is a Hong Kong politician and the former vice-chairman of the [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]]. He ran for many Legislative Council and District Council elections and was elected as [[Sha Tin District Council]]lor in 2003. He is also in charge of many pressure groups and protests of the [[pro-democracy camp]]. ==Positions held== * Vice Chairman, [[Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China]] * Vice Chairman, [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]] * Deputy Convenor, [[Alliance for Universal Suffrage]] * Executive Committee Member, [[Power for Democracy]] * Member, Hong Kong Human Rights Commission * Executive Committee Member, Amnesty International Hong Kong * Spokesman, Coalition to Monitor Public Transport and Utilities * Deputy Convenor, Health Care Policy Forum * Convenor, The Shatin Union for People's Livelihood * Chair, Sha Tin Youth Right Association[https://www.facebook.com/yctsoi/info Richard Tsoi's Facebook] ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Emily Lau]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Vice Chairperson of [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]] |alongside=[[Lo Kin-hei]]|years=2012–2014}} {{s-aft|after=[[Andrew Wan]]}} {{S-end}} {{HK Democratic Party}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tsoi, Richard}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hong Kong journalists]] [[Category:District councillors of Sha Tin District]] [[Category:Alumni of the Chinese University of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Charter 08 signatories]] [[Category:The Frontier (Hong Kong) politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Party (Hong Kong) politicians]] [[Category:HKFS people]]

{{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[19th-century philosophy|19th-]]/[[20th-century philosophy]] |image = Eucken-im-Alter.png |caption = |name = Rudolf Christoph Eucken |birth_date = {{birth date|1846|1|5|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Aurich]], [[Kingdom of Hanover]], [[German Confederation|Germany]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1926|9|15|1846|1|5|df=y}} |death_place = [[Jena]], [[Thuringia]], [[Weimar Republic|Germany]] |alma_mater = [[Göttingen University]]
[[Berlin University]] |institutions = [[University of Jena]]
[[University of Basel]] |school_tradition = [[Continental philosophy]]
[[German Idealism]] |main_interests = [[Ethics]] |notable_ideas = ''Aktivismus'' ([[ethical activism]])[[W. R. Boyce Gibson]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=RWc2V_JnKTMC&dq= ''Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy of Life''], Kessinger Publishing, 2004, p. 170.
[[The Real#In philosophy|The Real]] |influences = [[Aristotle]], [[Thomas Aquinas]], [[Gustav Teichmüller|Teichmüller]], [[Hermann Lotze|Lotze]], [[Friedrich Adolf Trendelenburg|Trendelenburg]] |influenced = [[Max Scheler]]
[[W. R. Boyce Gibson]][https://books.google.com/books?id=sMffGQKgJ9EC&dq= ''Kierkegaard Research: Sources, Reception and Resources, Volume 8, Tome III''], Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2009, p. 177.
[[Abel J. Jones]]
[[Evelyn Underhill]] |signature = Rudolf Eucken (signature).jpg |awards = [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] (1908) }} '''Rudolf Christoph Eucken''' ({{IPA-de|ˈɔʏkn̩|lang}}; 5 January 1846 – 15 September 1926) was a [[Germany|German]] [[philosopher]]. He received the 1908 [[Nobel Prize for Literature]] "in recognition of his earnest search for truth, his penetrating power of thought, his wide range of vision, and the warmth and strength in presentation with which in his numerous works he has vindicated and developed an idealistic philosophy of life", after he had been nominated by a member of the [[Swedish Academy]].[https://www.nobelprize.org/nomination/archive/show.php?id=3471 nobelprize.org] ==Early life== Eucken was born on 5 January 1846 in [[Aurich]], then in the [[Kingdom of Hanover]] (now [[Lower Saxony]]). His father, Ammo Becker Eucken (1792–1851) died when he was a child, and he was brought up by his mother, Ida Maria (1814–1872, née Gittermann). He was educated at Aurich, where one of his teachers was the classical philologist and philosopher Ludwig Wilhelm Maximilian Reuter (1803–1881).{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Eucken, Rudolf Christoph}} He studied at [[Göttingen University]] (1863–66), where [[Hermann Lotze]] was one of his teachers, and [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.deutsche-biographie.de/sfz19591.html|title=Biografie Rudolf Christoph Eucken (German)|publisher=Bayerische Nationalbibliothek|accessdate=5 August 2015}} In the latter place, [[Friedrich Adolf Trendelenburg]] was a professor whose ethical tendencies and historical treatment of philosophy greatly attracted him. ==Career== Eucken received his [[Ph.D.]] in classical [[philology]] and ancient [[history]] at [[Göttingen University]] in 1866 with a dissertation under the title ''De Aristotelis dicendi ratione''.The dissertation is available [https://archive.org/details/dearistotelisdi00euckgoog online at Internet Archive]. However, the inclination of his mind was definitely towards the philosophical side of [[theology]]. In 1871, after five years working as a school teacher at [[Husum]], Berlin und [[Frankfurt]], he was appointed Professor of [[Philosophy]] at the [[University of Basel]], [[Switzerland]], succeeding another of his former teachers at Göttingen, [[Gustav Teichmüller]]. He stayed there until 1874 when he took up a similar position at the [[University of Jena]]. He stayed there until he retired in 1920. In 1912-13, Eucken spent half of the year as an exchange professor at Harvard University, and in 1913 he served as a Deem lecturer at [[New York University]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L3Q7AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq=rudolf+eucken+harvard+university&source=bl&ots=8EUvlhqgGU&sig=6ECFFeU4QB3DLpomwooKz8gNtRQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYlN3giOvZAhVM7IMKHXDJCCMQ6AEISjAH#v=onepage&q=rudolf%20eucken%20harvard%20university&f=false|title=Harvard University Catalogue|last=University|first=Harvard|date=1912|publisher=The University.|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1908/eucken-bio.html|title=Rudolf Eucken - Biographical|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-03-14}} During [[World War I]], Eucken, like many of his academic colleagues, took a strong line in favour of the causes with which his country had associated itself.{{Cite EB1922|wstitle=Eucken, Rudolf Christoph}} [[File:Aurich, Ostfriesland, Osterstraße 27, Geburtshaus von Rudolf Eucken (2).JPG|thumb|Birthplace of Rudolf Eucken in Aurich, Osterstraße 27 (September 2015)]] ==Ethical activism== Eucken's philosophical work is partly historical and partly constructive, the former side being predominant in his earlier, the latter in his later works. Their most striking feature is the close organic relationship between the two parts. The aim of the historical works is to show the necessary connexion between philosophical concepts and the age to which they belong; the same idea is at the root of his constructive speculation. All philosophy is [[philosophy of life]], the development of a new culture, not mere intellectualism, but the application of a vital religious inspiration to the practical problems of society. This practical idealism Eucken described by the term "'''ethical activism'''." In accordance with this principle, Eucken gave considerable attention to social and educational problems. He maintained that humans have [[soul]]s, and that they are therefore at the junction between nature and spirit. He believed that people should overcome their non-spiritual nature by continuous efforts to achieve a [[spirituality|spiritual]] life, another aspect of his ethical activism and [[meaning of life]]. ==Later life and death== He married Irene Passow (1863–1941) in 1882 and had a daughter and two sons. His son [[Walter Eucken]] became a famous founder of [[Ordoliberalism|ordoliberal]] thought in [[Neoliberal economics|economics]]. His son [[Arnold Eucken]] was a chemist/physicist. Rudolf Eucken died on 15 September 1926 in [[Jena]] at the age of 80. ==Major works== He was a prolific writer; his best-known works are: * [https://archive.org/details/dielebensanschau00euckuoft ''Die Lebensanschauungen der großen Denker''] (1890; 7th ed., 1907; 1918; Eng. trans., W. Hough and Boyce Gibson, ''The Problem of Human Life'', 1909) (The Problem of Human Life as Viewed by the Great Thinkers) * ''Der Kampf um einen geistigen Lebensinhalt'' (1896) (The Struggle for a Spiritual Content of Life) * [https://archive.org/details/derwahrheitsgeh00euckgoog ''Der Wahrheitsgehalt der Religion''] (1901) (The Truth of Religion) * [https://archive.org/details/grundlinieneine00euckgoog ''Grundlinien einer neuen Lebensanschauung''] (1907) (Life's Basis and Life's Ideal: The Fundamentals of a New Philosophy of Life) * [https://archive.org/stream/dersinnundwertde00euck#page/n3/mode/2up ''Der Sinn und Wert des Lebens''] (1908) (The Meaning and Value of Life) * ''Geistige Strömungen der Gegenwart'' (1908; first appeared in 1878 as [https://archive.org/details/diegrundbegriff01euckgoog ''Die Grundbegriffe der Gegenwart'']; Eng. trans. by M. Stuart Phelps, New York, 1880) (Main Currents of Modern Thought) * ''Können wir noch Christen sein?'' (1911) ([https://archive.org/details/canwestillbechri00euck Can We Still Be Christians?], 1914)) * ''Present Day Ethics in their Relation to the Spiritual Life'' (1913) (Deem Lectures given at New York University) * ''Der Sozialismus und seine Lebensgestaltung'' (1920) ([https://archive.org/details/socialismanalysi00euck Socialism: an Analysis] (1922)) Other notable works are: * ''Die Methode der aristotelischen Forschung'' (1872) (The Aristotelian Method of Research) * ''Geschichte der philosophische Terminologie'' (1879) (History of Philosophical Terminology) * ''Prolegomena zu Forschungen über die Einheit des Geisteslebens'' (1885) (Prolegomena to Research on the Unity of the Spiritual Life) * ''Beiträge zur Geschichte der neueren Philosophie'' (1886, 1905) (Contributions to the History of the Newer Philosophies) * ''Die Einheit des Geisteslebens'' (1888) (The Unity of the Spiritual Life) * [https://archive.org/details/thomasvonaquino00euck ''Thomas von Aquino und Kant''] (1901) (Thomas Aquinas and Kant) * ''Gesammelte Aufsätze zu Philosophische und Lebensanschauung (1903) (Collected Essays on Views of Philosophy and Life) * ''Philosophie der Geschichte'' (1907) (Philosophy of History) * ''Einführung in die Philosophie der Geisteslebens'' (1908; Eng. trans., The Life of the Spirit, F. L. Pogson, 1909, Crown Theological Library) (Introduction to the Philosophy of the Life of the Spirit) * [https://archive.org/details/hauptproblemeder00euckuoft ''Hauptprobleme der Religionsphilosophie der Gegenwart''] (1907) (Main Problems of the Current Philosophy of Religion) Other English translations of his work include: * ''Liberty in Teaching in the German Universities'' (1897) * ''Are the Germans still a Nation of Thinkers?'' (1898) * ''Progress of Philosophy in the 19th Century'' (1899) * ''The Finnish Question'' (1899) * ''The Present Status of Religion in Germany'' (1901) * [https://archive.org/stream/problemhumanlif01euckgoog#page/n8/mode/2up ''The Problem of Human Life as Viewed by the Great Thinkers from Plato to the Present Time''], Charles Scribner's Sons, 1909. * [https://archive.org/details/backtoreligion00euckrich ''Back to Religion''], 1912. * [https://archive.org/stream/maincurrentsmode00euckuoft#page/n5/mode/2up ''Main Currents of Modern Thought: A Study of the Spiritual and Intellectual Movements of the Present Day''], T. Fisher Unwin, 1912. * [https://archive.org/stream/themeaningandval00euckuoft#page/n5/mode/2up ''The Meaning and Value of Life''], A. and C. Black, 1913. * [https://archive.org/stream/canwestillbechri00euckrich#page/n5/mode/2up ''Can we Still be Christians?''], The Macmillan Company, 1914. * [https://archive.org/stream/collectedessayso00euckuoft#page/n7/mode/2up ''Collected Essays''], T. Fisher Unwin, 1914. * [https://archive.org/details/knowledgelife00euck ''Knowledge and Life''] (translation), G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1914. He delivered lectures in England in 1911 and spent six months lecturing at [[Harvard University]] and elsewhere in the United States in 1912–1913. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Beck, Friedrich Alfred. ''Rudolf Eucken,'' Deutsche Buch-Gemeinschaft, 1927. * Booth, Meyrick. [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924029089377#page/n5/mode/2up ''Rudolf Eucken: His Philosophy and Influence,''] Charles Scribner's Sons, 1913. * Feuling, Daniel. [https://archive.org/stream/dublinreview155londuoft#page/62/mode/2up ''"Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy,"''] The Dublin Review, Vol. CLV, July/October, 1914. * Gibson, W. R. Boyce. [https://archive.org/stream/rudolfeuckensphi00gibs#page/n7/mode/2up ''Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy of Life,''] A. & C. Black, 1915. * Jones, Abel J. [https://archive.org/stream/rudolfeuckenphil00joneiala#page/n5/mode/2up ''Rudolf Eucken: A Philosophy of Life,''] T. C. & E. C. Jack, 1913. * Jones, W. Tudor. ''Rudolf Eucken: His Life and Philosophy,'' Haldeman-Julius Co., 1920. * MacSwiney, Margaret Mary. {{Other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Sam Houston |image = Sam Houston c1850-crop.jpg |caption = Sam Houston, circa 1850 |order = 7th [[Governor of Texas]] |term_start = December 21, 1859 |term_end = March 16, 1861 |lieutenant = Edward Clark |predecessor = [[Hardin Richard Runnels]] |successor = [[Edward Clark (governor)|Edward Clark]] |jr/sr1 = United States Senator |state1 = [[Texas]] |term_start1 = February 21, 1846 |term_end1 = March 4, 1859 |predecessor1 = ''Seat established'' |successor1 = [[John Hemphill (senator)|John Hemphill]] |order3 = 1st and 3rd [[President of the Republic of Texas|President]] of the [[Republic of Texas]] |vicepresident3 = [[Edward Burleson]] |term_start3 = December 21, 1841 |term_end3 = December 9, 1844 |predecessor3 = [[Mirabeau B. Lamar]] |state_house5 = Texas |district5 = [[San Augustine, Texas|San Augustine]] |term_start6 = 1839 |term_end6 = 1841 |order7 = 6th |office7 = Governor of Tennessee |lieutenant7 = [[William Hall (governor)|William Hall]] |term_start7 = October 1, 1827 |term_end7 = April 16, 1829 |predecessor7 = [[William Carroll (Tennessee politician)|William Carroll]] |successor7 = [[William Hall (governor)|William Hall]] |district8 = {{ushr|TN|7|7th}} |state8 = [[Tennessee]] |term_start8 = March 4, 1823 |term_end8 = March 4, 1827 |predecessor8 = ''Constituency established'' |successor8 = [[John Bell (Tennessee politician)|John Bell]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1793|3|2}} |birth_place = [[Rockbridge County, Virginia]], U.S. |death_date = {{Death date and age|1863|7|26|1793|3|2}} |death_place = [[Huntsville, Texas]] |resting_place = Oakwood Cemetery

Independent (after 1856) |signature = Sam Houston signature.svg |allegiance = [[United States|United States of America]]
